column2: '15Oct'
column3: 1)	" Let's go.

column1: That's right at the top of my agenda. We've shipped millions of jobs overseas and we have a strange situation because we have a process in Washington where after you've served for a while you cash in
column2: become a foreign lobbyist
column3: make $30
column4: 000 a month
column6: work on presidential campaigns
column7: make sure you've got good contacts and then go back out. Now
column8: if you just want to get down to brass tacks
column9: first thing you ought to do is get all these folks who've got these 1-way trade agreements that we've negotiated over the years and say fellas
column10: we'll take the same deal we gave you. And they'll gridlock right at that point because for example
column11: we've got international competitors who simply could not unload their cars off the ships if they had to comply -- you see
column12: if it was a 2-way street
column13: just couldn't do it. We have got to stop sending jobs overseas.  To those of you in the audience who are business people: pretty simple. If you're paying $12
column15: $14 an hour for a factory worker
column16: and you can move your factory south of the border
column17: pay $1 an hour for labor
column18: hire a young -- let's assume you've been in business for a long time. You've got a mature workforce. Pay $1 an hour for your labor
column19: have no health care -- that's the most expensive single element in making the car. Have no environmental controls
column20: no pollution controls and no retirement. And you don't care about anything but making money. There will be a job-sucking sound going south.  If the people send me to Washington the first thing I'll do is study that 2000-page agreement and make sure it's a 2-way street.  One last point here. I decided I was dumb and didn't understand it so I called a ""Who's Who"" of the folks that have been around it
column21: and I said why won't everybody go south; they said it will be disruptive; I said for how long. I finally got 'em for 12 to 15 years. And I said
column23: how does it stop being disruptive? And that is when their jobs come up from a dollar an hour to $6 an hour
column24: and ours go down to $6 an hour; then it's leveled again
column25: but in the meantime you've wrecked the country with these kind of deals. We got to cut it out.

column1: Carole
column2: the thing that saved us in this global economic slowdown has been our exports
column3: and what I'm trying to do is increase our exports. And if indeed all the jobs were going to move south because there are lower wages
column4: there are lower wages now and they haven't done that. And so I have just negotiated with the president of Mexico the North American Free Trade Agreement -- and the prime minister of Canada
column5: I might add -- and I want to have more of these free trade agreements
column6: because export jobs are increasing far faster than any jobs that may have moved overseas. That's a scare tactic
column7: because it's not that many. But any one that's here
column8: we want to have more jobs here. And the way to do that is to increase our exports. Some believe in protection. I don't; I believe in free and fair trade
column9: and that's the thing that saved us. So I will keep on as president trying to get a successful conclusion to the GATT Round
column10: the big Uruguay Round of trade which will really open up markets for our agriculture particularly. I want to continue to work after we get this NAFTA agreement ratified this coming year. I want to get one with Eastern Europe; I want to get one with Chile. And free and fair trade is the answer
column11: not protection.  And
column12: as I say
column13: we've had tough economic times
column14: and it's exports that have saved us
column15: exports that have built.

column1: I'd like to answer the question
column2: because I've actually been a governor for 12 years
column3: so I've known a lot of people who have lost their jobs because of jobs moving overseas
column4: and I know a lot of people whose plants have been strengthened by increasing exports. The trick is to expand our export base and to expand trade on terms that are fair to us. It is true that our exports to Mexico
column6: have gone up and our trade deficit has gone down; it's also true that just today a record high trade deficit was announced with Japan.  So what is the answer? Let me just mention three things very quickly. Number one
column7: make sure that other countries are as open to our markets as our markets are to them
column8: and
column9: if they're not
column10: have measures on the books that don't take forever and a day to implement.  Number two
column11: change the tax code. There are more deductions in the tax code for shutting plants down and moving overseas than there are for modernizing plant and equipment here. Our competitors don't do that. Emphasize and subsidize modernizing plant and equipment here
column12: not moving plants overseas.  Number three
column13: stop the federal government's program that now gives low-interest loans and job training funds to companies that will actually shut down and move to other countries
column14: but we won't do the same thing for plants that stay here.  So more trade but on fair terms -- and favor investment in America.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 2)	" No
column4: and here's why. And I'll tell you exactly why. Because the deficit now has been building up for 12 years. I'll tell you exactly what I think can be done. I think we can bring it down by 50% in 4 years and grow the economy. Now
column5: I could get rid of it in 4 years in theory on the books now
column6: but to do it you'd have to raise taxes too much and cut benefits too much to people who need them and it would even make the economy worse. Mr. Perot will tell you
column7: for example
column8: that the expert he hired to analyze his plan says that it will bring the deficit down in 5 years but it will make unemployment bad for 4 more years. So my view is
column9: sir
column10: you have to increase investment
column11: grow the economy and reduce the deficit by controlling health care costs
column12: prudent reductions in defense
column13: cuts in domestic programs and asking the wealthiest Americans and foreign corporations to pay their fair share of taxes and investing and growing this economy.  I ask everybody to look at my economic ideas and 9 Nobel prize winners and over 500 economists and hundreds of business people
column14: including a lot of Republicans said
column15: this is the way you've got to go. If you don't grow the economy you can't get it done. But I can't foresee all the things that will happen
column16: and I don't think a president should be judged solely on the deficit.  Let me also say
column17: we're having an election today. You'll have a shot at me in 4 years and you can vote me right out if you think I've done a lousy job and I would welcome you to do that.

column1: Well
column2: I'm a little confused here
column3: because I don't see how you can grow the deficit down by raising people's taxes. You see
column4: I don't think the American people are taxed too little. I think they're taxed too much. I went for one tax increase and when I make a mistake I admit it. I said that wasn't the right thing to do. Governor Clinton's program wants to tax more and spend more -- $150 billion in new taxes
column5: spend another $220. I don't believe that's the way to do it.  Here's some thing that'll help. Give us a balanced budget amendment. He always talks about Arkansas having a balanced budget and they do
column6: but he has a balanced budget amendment. Have to do it. I'd like the government to have that. And I think it would discipline not only the Congress
column7: which needs it
column8: but also the executive branch.  I'd like to have what 43 governors have -- the line item veto
column9: so if the Congress can't cut
column10: and we've got a reckless spending Congress
column11: let the president have a shot at it by wiping out things that are pork barrel or something of that nature.  I've proposed another one. Some sophisticates think it may be a little gimmicky. I think it's good. It's a check- off. It says to you as a taxpayer -- say you're going to pay a tax of 1000 bucks or something. You can check 10% of that if you want to
column12: in the 1 box
column13: and that 10%
column15: or if you're paying $10
column17: whatever it is
column19: check it off and make the government
column20: make it lower the deficit by that amount.  And if the Congress won't do it
column21: if they can't get together and negotiate how to do that
column22: then you'd have a sequester across the board. You'd exempt Social Security -- I don't want to tax or touch Social Security. I'm the president that said hey
column23: don't mess with Social Security
column24: and we haven't.  So I believe that we need to control the growth of mandatory spending
column25: back to this gentleman's question. That's the main growing thing in the budget. The program that the president -- two-thirds of the budget
column26: I as president never get to look at
column27: never get to touch. We've got to control that growth to inflation and population increase
column28: but not raise taxes on the American people now. I just don't believe that would stimulate any kind of growth at all.

column1: Well
column2: we're $4 trillion in debt. We're going into debt an additional $1 billion
column3: little more than $1 billion every working day of the year. Now
column4: the thing I love about it -- I'm just a businessman. I was down in Texas taking care of business
column5: tending to my family. This situation got so bad that I decided I'd better get into it. The American people asked me to get into it. But I just find it fascinating that while we sit here tonight we will go into debt an additional $50 million in an hour and a half.  Now
column6: it's not the Republicans' fault
column7: of course
column8: and it's not the Democrats' fault. And what I'm looking for is who did it? Now
column9: they're the 2 folks involved so maybe if you put them together
column10: they did it.  Now
column11: the facts are we have to fix it. I'm here tonight for these young people up here in the balcony from this college. When I was a young man
column12: when I got out of the Navy I had multiple job offers. Young people with high grades can't get a job. People -- the 18- to 24-year-old high school graduates 10 years ago were making more than they are now. In other words
column13: we were down to 18% of them were making -- 18- to 24-year- olds were making less than $12
column14: 000. Now that's up to 40%. And what's happened in the meantime? The dollar's gone through the floor.  Now
column15: whose fault is that? Not the Democrats. Not the Republicans. Somewhere out there there's an extraterrestrial that's doing this to us
column16: I guess. And everybody says they take responsibility. Somebody somewhere has to take responsibility for this.  Put it to you bluntly
column17: American people. If you want me to be your president
column18: we're going to face our problems. We'll deal with our problems
column19: we'll solve our problems. We'll down our debt. We'll pass on the American dream to our children
column20: and I will not leave our children a situation that they have today.  When I was a boy it took 2 generations to double the standard of living. Today it will take 12 generations. Our children will not see the American dream because of this debt that somebody somewhere dropped on us.

column3: 2)	" No
column4: and here's why. And I'll tell you exactly why. Because the deficit now has been building up for 12 years. I'll tell you exactly what I think can be done. I think we can bring it down by 50% in 4 years and grow the economy. Now
column5: I could get rid of it in 4 years in theory on the books now
column6: but to do it you'd have to raise taxes too much and cut benefits too much to people who need them and it would even make the economy worse. Mr. Perot will tell you
column7: for example
column8: that the expert he hired to analyze his plan says that it will bring the deficit down in 5 years but it will make unemployment bad for 4 more years. So my view is
column9: sir
column10: you have to increase investment
column11: grow the economy and reduce the deficit by controlling health care costs
column12: prudent reductions in defense
column13: cuts in domestic programs and asking the wealthiest Americans and foreign corporations to pay their fair share of taxes and investing and growing this economy.  I ask everybody to look at my economic ideas and 9 Nobel prize winners and over 500 economists and hundreds of business people
column14: including a lot of Republicans said
column15: this is the way you've got to go. If you don't grow the economy you can't get it done. But I can't foresee all the things that will happen
column16: and I don't think a president should be judged solely on the deficit.  Let me also say
column17: we're having an election today. You'll have a shot at me in 4 years and you can vote me right out if you think I've done a lousy job and I would welcome you to do that.

column1: Well
column2: I'm a little confused here
column3: because I don't see how you can grow the deficit down by raising people's taxes. You see
column4: I don't think the American people are taxed too little. I think they're taxed too much. I went for one tax increase and when I make a mistake I admit it. I said that wasn't the right thing to do. Governor Clinton's program wants to tax more and spend more -- $150 billion in new taxes
column5: spend another $220. I don't believe that's the way to do it.  Here's some thing that'll help. Give us a balanced budget amendment. He always talks about Arkansas having a balanced budget and they do
column6: but he has a balanced budget amendment. Have to do it. I'd like the government to have that. And I think it would discipline not only the Congress
column7: which needs it
column8: but also the executive branch.  I'd like to have what 43 governors have -- the line item veto
column9: so if the Congress can't cut
column10: and we've got a reckless spending Congress
column11: let the president have a shot at it by wiping out things that are pork barrel or something of that nature.  I've proposed another one. Some sophisticates think it may be a little gimmicky. I think it's good. It's a check- off. It says to you as a taxpayer -- say you're going to pay a tax of 1000 bucks or something. You can check 10% of that if you want to
column12: in the 1 box
column13: and that 10%
column15: or if you're paying $10
column17: whatever it is
column19: check it off and make the government
column20: make it lower the deficit by that amount.  And if the Congress won't do it
column21: if they can't get together and negotiate how to do that
column22: then you'd have a sequester across the board. You'd exempt Social Security -- I don't want to tax or touch Social Security. I'm the president that said hey
column23: don't mess with Social Security
column24: and we haven't.  So I believe that we need to control the growth of mandatory spending
column25: back to this gentleman's question. That's the main growing thing in the budget. The program that the president -- two-thirds of the budget
column26: I as president never get to look at
column27: never get to touch. We've got to control that growth to inflation and population increase
column28: but not raise taxes on the American people now. I just don't believe that would stimulate any kind of growth at all.

column1: Well
column2: we're $4 trillion in debt. We're going into debt an additional $1 billion
column3: little more than $1 billion every working day of the year. Now
column4: the thing I love about it -- I'm just a businessman. I was down in Texas taking care of business
column5: tending to my family. This situation got so bad that I decided I'd better get into it. The American people asked me to get into it. But I just find it fascinating that while we sit here tonight we will go into debt an additional $50 million in an hour and a half.  Now
column6: it's not the Republicans' fault
column7: of course
column8: and it's not the Democrats' fault. And what I'm looking for is who did it? Now
column9: they're the 2 folks involved so maybe if you put them together
column10: they did it.  Now
column11: the facts are we have to fix it. I'm here tonight for these young people up here in the balcony from this college. When I was a young man
column12: when I got out of the Navy I had multiple job offers. Young people with high grades can't get a job. People -- the 18- to 24-year-old high school graduates 10 years ago were making more than they are now. In other words
column13: we were down to 18% of them were making -- 18- to 24-year- olds were making less than $12
column14: 000. Now that's up to 40%. And what's happened in the meantime? The dollar's gone through the floor.  Now
column15: whose fault is that? Not the Democrats. Not the Republicans. Somewhere out there there's an extraterrestrial that's doing this to us
column16: I guess. And everybody says they take responsibility. Somebody somewhere has to take responsibility for this.  Put it to you bluntly
column17: American people. If you want me to be your president
column18: we're going to face our problems. We'll deal with our problems
column19: we'll solve our problems. We'll down our debt. We'll pass on the American dream to our children
column20: and I will not leave our children a situation that they have today.  When I was a boy it took 2 generations to double the standard of living. Today it will take 12 generations. Our children will not see the American dream because of this debt that somebody somewhere dropped on us.

column13: cuts in domestic programs and asking the wealthiest Americans and foreign corporations to pay their fair share of taxes and investing and growing this economy.  I ask everybody to look at my economic ideas and 9 Nobel prize winners and over 500 economists and hundreds of business people
column14: including a lot of Republicans said
column15: this is the way you've got to go. If you don't grow the economy you can't get it done. But I can't foresee all the things that will happen
column16: and I don't think a president should be judged solely on the deficit.  Let me also say
column17: we're having an election today. You'll have a shot at me in 4 years and you can vote me right out if you think I've done a lousy job and I would welcome you to do that.

column1: Well
column2: I'm a little confused here
column3: because I don't see how you can grow the deficit down by raising people's taxes. You see
column4: I don't think the American people are taxed too little. I think they're taxed too much. I went for one tax increase and when I make a mistake I admit it. I said that wasn't the right thing to do. Governor Clinton's program wants to tax more and spend more -- $150 billion in new taxes
column5: spend another $220. I don't believe that's the way to do it.  Here's some thing that'll help. Give us a balanced budget amendment. He always talks about Arkansas having a balanced budget and they do
column6: but he has a balanced budget amendment. Have to do it. I'd like the government to have that. And I think it would discipline not only the Congress
column7: which needs it
column8: but also the executive branch.  I'd like to have what 43 governors have -- the line item veto
column9: so if the Congress can't cut
column10: and we've got a reckless spending Congress
column11: let the president have a shot at it by wiping out things that are pork barrel or something of that nature.  I've proposed another one. Some sophisticates think it may be a little gimmicky. I think it's good. It's a check- off. It says to you as a taxpayer -- say you're going to pay a tax of 1000 bucks or something. You can check 10% of that if you want to
column12: in the 1 box
column13: and that 10%
column15: or if you're paying $10
column17: whatever it is
column19: check it off and make the government
column20: make it lower the deficit by that amount.  And if the Congress won't do it
column21: if they can't get together and negotiate how to do that
column22: then you'd have a sequester across the board. You'd exempt Social Security -- I don't want to tax or touch Social Security. I'm the president that said hey
column23: don't mess with Social Security
column24: and we haven't.  So I believe that we need to control the growth of mandatory spending
column25: back to this gentleman's question. That's the main growing thing in the budget. The program that the president -- two-thirds of the budget
column26: I as president never get to look at
column27: never get to touch. We've got to control that growth to inflation and population increase
column28: but not raise taxes on the American people now. I just don't believe that would stimulate any kind of growth at all.

column1: Well
column2: we're $4 trillion in debt. We're going into debt an additional $1 billion
column3: little more than $1 billion every working day of the year. Now
column4: the thing I love about it -- I'm just a businessman. I was down in Texas taking care of business
column5: tending to my family. This situation got so bad that I decided I'd better get into it. The American people asked me to get into it. But I just find it fascinating that while we sit here tonight we will go into debt an additional $50 million in an hour and a half.  Now
column6: it's not the Republicans' fault
column7: of course
column8: and it's not the Democrats' fault. And what I'm looking for is who did it? Now
column9: they're the 2 folks involved so maybe if you put them together
column10: they did it.  Now
column11: the facts are we have to fix it. I'm here tonight for these young people up here in the balcony from this college. When I was a young man
column12: when I got out of the Navy I had multiple job offers. Young people with high grades can't get a job. People -- the 18- to 24-year-old high school graduates 10 years ago were making more than they are now. In other words
column13: we were down to 18% of them were making -- 18- to 24-year- olds were making less than $12
column14: 000. Now that's up to 40%. And what's happened in the meantime? The dollar's gone through the floor.  Now
column15: whose fault is that? Not the Democrats. Not the Republicans. Somewhere out there there's an extraterrestrial that's doing this to us
column16: I guess. And everybody says they take responsibility. Somebody somewhere has to take responsibility for this.  Put it to you bluntly
column17: American people. If you want me to be your president
column18: we're going to face our problems. We'll deal with our problems
column19: we'll solve our problems. We'll down our debt. We'll pass on the American dream to our children
column20: and I will not leave our children a situation that they have today.  When I was a boy it took 2 generations to double the standard of living. Today it will take 12 generations. Our children will not see the American dream because of this debt that somebody somewhere dropped on us.

column3: 3)	" No
column4: I don't have an answer for everything. As you all know
column5: I've been buying 30-minute segments to talk about issues. And tomorrow night on NBC
column6: from 10:30 to 11 Eastern
column7: we're going to talk about how you pay the debt down
column8: so we're going to come right down to that one. We'll be on again Saturday night
column9: 8 to 9 o'clock on ABC. So the point is --

column1: Like Jerry Brown
column2: the 800 number.

column1: -- I couldn't agree with you more
column2: couldn't agree with you more. And I have said again and again and again let's get off mud wrestling
column3: let's get off personalities and let's talk about jobs
column4: health care
column6: the things that concern the American people. I'm spending my money -- not PAC money
column7: not foreign money
column8: my money -- to take this message to the people.

column1: Well
column2: in the first place
column3: I believe that character is a part of being president. I think you have to look at it. I think that has to be a part of a candidate for president or being president. In terms of programs
column4: I've submitted
column6: 4 different budgets to the US Congress in great detail. It's so heavy they'd give you a broken back. And everything in there says what I am for. Now I've come out with a new agenda for America's renewal
column7: a plan that I believe really will help stimulate the growth of this economy. My record on world affairs is pretty well known because I've been president for 4 years
column8: so I feel I've been talking issues.  You know
column9: nobody likes who shot John
column10: but I think the first negative campaign run in this election was by Governor Clinton
column11: and I'm not going to sit there and be a punching bag; I'm going to stand up and say
column12: hey
column13: listen
column14: here's my side of it.  But character is an important part of the equation. The other night Governor Clinton raised my -- I don't know if you saw the debate the other night. You did -- suffered through that? Well
column15: he raised the question of my father -- it was a good line
column16: well rehearsed and well delivered. But he raised the question of my father and said
column17: well
column18: your father
column20: was against McCarthy
column21: you should be ashamed of yourself
column22: McCarthyism. I remember something my dad told me -- I was 18 years old going to Penn Station to go on into the Navy
column23: and he said write your mother -- which I faithfully did; he said serve your country -- my father was an honor
column24: duty and country man; and he said tell the truth. And I've tried to do that in public life
column25: all through it. That says something about character.  My argument with Governor Clinton -- you can call it mud wrestling
column26: but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war. Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me. But that's what I feel. That's what I feel passionately about. I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail. How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.  But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --

column1: Excuse me. I don't want to --
I don't want to --
I get wound up because I feel strongly --

Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

I couldn't agree with you more, couldn't agree with you more. column1: -- I couldn't agree with you more
column2: couldn't agree with you more. And I have said again and again and again let's get off mud wrestling
column3: let's get off personalities and let's talk about jobs
column4: health care

column1: Well
column2: in the first place
column3: I believe that character is a part of being president. I think you have to look at it. I think that has to be a part of a candidate for president or being president. In terms of programs
column4: I've submitted
column6: 4 different budgets to the US Congress in great detail. It's so heavy they'd give you a broken back. And everything in there says what I am for. Now I've come out with a new agenda for America's renewal
column7: a plan that I believe really will help stimulate the growth of this economy. My record on world affairs is pretty well known because I've been president for 4 years
column8: so I feel I've been talking issues.  You know
column9: nobody likes who shot John
column10: but I think the first negative campaign run in this election was by Governor Clinton
column11: and I'm not going to sit there and be a punching bag; I'm going to stand up and say
column12: hey
column13: listen
column14: here's my side of it.  But character is an important part of the equation. The other night Governor Clinton raised my -- I don't know if you saw the debate the other night. You did -- suffered through that? Well
column15: he raised the question of my father -- it was a good line
column16: well rehearsed and well delivered. But he raised the question of my father and said
column17: well
column18: your father
column20: was against McCarthy
column21: you should be ashamed of yourself
column22: McCarthyism. I remember something my dad told me -- I was 18 years old going to Penn Station to go on into the Navy
column23: and he said write your mother -- which I faithfully did; he said serve your country -- my father was an honor
column24: duty and country man; and he said tell the truth. And I've tried to do that in public life
column25: all through it. That says something about character.  My argument with Governor Clinton -- you can call it mud wrestling
column26: but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war. Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me. But that's what I feel. That's what I feel passionately about. I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail. How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.  But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --

column1: Excuse me. I don't want to --
I don't want to --
I get wound up because I feel strongly --

Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

I couldn't agree with you more, couldn't agree with you more. Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

And I have said again and again and again let's get off mud wrestling, let's get off personalities and let's talk about jobs, health care, crime, the things that concern the American people. column26: but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war. Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me. But that's what I feel. That's what I feel passionately about. I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail. How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.  But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --

column1: Excuse me. I don't want to --
I don't want to --
I get wound up because I feel strongly --

Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

And I have said again and again and again let's get off mud wrestling, let's get off personalities and let's talk about jobs, health care, crime, the things that concern the American people. column4: I don't have an answer for everything. As you all know
column5: I've been buying 30-minute segments to talk about issues. And tomorrow night on NBC
column6: from 10:30 to 11 Eastern
column7: we're going to talk about how you pay the debt down

column1: Like Jerry Brown
column2: the 800 number.

column1: -- I couldn't agree with you more
column2: couldn't agree with you more. And I have said again and again and again let's get off mud wrestling
column3: let's get off personalities and let's talk about jobs
column4: health care
column6: the things that concern the American people. I'm spending my money -- not PAC money
column7: not foreign money
column8: my money -- to take this message to the people.

column1: Well
column2: in the first place
column3: I believe that character is a part of being president. I think you have to look at it. I think that has to be a part of a candidate for president or being president. In terms of programs
column4: I've submitted
column6: 4 different budgets to the US Congress in great detail. It's so heavy they'd give you a broken back. And everything in there says what I am for. Now I've come out with a new agenda for America's renewal
column7: a plan that I believe really will help stimulate the growth of this economy. My record on world affairs is pretty well known because I've been president for 4 years
column8: so I feel I've been talking issues.  You know
column9: nobody likes who shot John
column10: but I think the first negative campaign run in this election was by Governor Clinton
column11: and I'm not going to sit there and be a punching bag; I'm going to stand up and say
column12: hey
column13: listen
column14: here's my side of it.  But character is an important part of the equation. The other night Governor Clinton raised my -- I don't know if you saw the debate the other night. You did -- suffered through that? Well
column15: he raised the question of my father -- it was a good line
column16: well rehearsed and well delivered. But he raised the question of my father and said
column17: well
column18: your father
column20: was against McCarthy
column21: you should be ashamed of yourself
column22: McCarthyism. I remember something my dad told me -- I was 18 years old going to Penn Station to go on into the Navy
column23: and he said write your mother -- which I faithfully did; he said serve your country -- my father was an honor
column24: duty and country man; and he said tell the truth. And I've tried to do that in public life
column25: all through it. That says something about character.  My argument with Governor Clinton -- you can call it mud wrestling
column26: but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war. Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me. But that's what I feel. That's what I feel passionately about. I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail. How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.  But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --

column1: Excuse me. I don't want to --
I don't want to --
I get wound up because I feel strongly --

Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

You know, nobody likes who shot John, but I think the first negative campaign run in this election was by Governor Clinton, and I'm not going to sit there and be a punching bag; I'm going to stand up and say, hey, listen, here's my side of it. column1: Well
column2: in the first place
column3: I believe that character is a part of being president. I think you have to look at it. I think that has to be a part of a candidate for president or being president. In terms of programs
column4: I've submitted
column6: 4 different budgets to the US Congress in great detail. It's so heavy they'd give you a broken back. And everything in there says what I am for. Now I've come out with a new agenda for America's renewal
column7: a plan that I believe really will help stimulate the growth of this economy. My record on world affairs is pretty well known because I've been president for 4 years
column8: so I feel I've been talking issues.  You know
column9: nobody likes who shot John
column10: but I think the first negative campaign run in this election was by Governor Clinton
column11: and I'm not going to sit there and be a punching bag; I'm going to stand up and say
column12: hey
column13: listen
column14: here's my side of it.  But character is an important part of the equation. The other night Governor Clinton raised my -- I don't know if you saw the debate the other night. You did -- suffered through that? Well
column15: he raised the question of my father -- it was a good line
column16: well rehearsed and well delivered. But he raised the question of my father and said
column17: well
column18: your father
column20: was against McCarthy
column21: you should be ashamed of yourself
column22: McCarthyism. I remember something my dad told me -- I was 18 years old going to Penn Station to go on into the Navy
column23: and he said write your mother -- which I faithfully did; he said serve your country -- my father was an honor
column24: duty and country man; and he said tell the truth. And I've tried to do that in public life
column25: all through it. That says something about character.  My argument with Governor Clinton -- you can call it mud wrestling
column26: but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war. Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me. But that's what I feel. That's what I feel passionately about. I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail. How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.  But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --

column1: Excuse me. I don't want to --
I don't want to --
I get wound up because I feel strongly --

Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

You know, nobody likes who shot John, but I think the first negative campaign run in this election was by Governor Clinton, and I'm not going to sit there and be a punching bag; I'm going to stand up and say, hey, listen, here's my side of it. column1: Well
column2: in the first place
column3: I believe that character is a part of being president. I think you have to look at it. I think that has to be a part of a candidate for president or being president. In terms of programs
column4: I've submitted
column6: 4 different budgets to the US Congress in great detail. It's so heavy they'd give you a broken back. And everything in there says what I am for. Now I've come out with a new agenda for America's renewal
column7: a plan that I believe really will help stimulate the growth of this economy. My record on world affairs is pretty well known because I've been president for 4 years
column8: so I feel I've been talking issues.  You know
column9: nobody likes who shot John
column10: but I think the first negative campaign run in this election was by Governor Clinton
column11: and I'm not going to sit there and be a punching bag; I'm going to stand up and say
column12: hey
column13: listen
column14: here's my side of it.  But character is an important part of the equation. The other night Governor Clinton raised my -- I don't know if you saw the debate the other night. You did -- suffered through that? Well
column15: he raised the question of my father -- it was a good line
column16: well rehearsed and well delivered. But he raised the question of my father and said
column17: well
column18: your father
column20: was against McCarthy
column21: you should be ashamed of yourself
column22: McCarthyism. I remember something my dad told me -- I was 18 years old going to Penn Station to go on into the Navy
column23: and he said write your mother -- which I faithfully did; he said serve your country -- my father was an honor
column24: duty and country man; and he said tell the truth. And I've tried to do that in public life
column25: all through it. That says something about character.  My argument with Governor Clinton -- you can call it mud wrestling
column26: but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war. Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me. But that's what I feel. That's what I feel passionately about. I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail. How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.  But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --

column1: Excuse me. I don't want to --
I don't want to --
I get wound up because I feel strongly --

Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

You know, nobody likes who shot John, but I think the first negative campaign run in this election was by Governor Clinton, and I'm not going to sit there and be a punching bag; I'm going to stand up and say, hey, listen, here's my side of it. column16: well rehearsed and well delivered. But he raised the question of my father and said
column17: well
column18: your father
column20: was against McCarthy
column21: you should be ashamed of yourself
column22: McCarthyism. I remember something my dad told me -- I was 18 years old going to Penn Station to go on into the Navy
column23: and he said write your mother -- which I faithfully did; he said serve your country -- my father was an honor
column24: duty and country man; and he said tell the truth. And I've tried to do that in public life
column25: all through it. That says something about character.  My argument with Governor Clinton -- you can call it mud wrestling
column26: but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war. Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me. But that's what I feel. That's what I feel passionately about. I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail. How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.  But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --

column1: Excuse me. I don't want to --
I don't want to --
I get wound up because I feel strongly --

Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

You know, nobody likes who shot John, but I think the first negative campaign run in this election was by Governor Clinton, and I'm not going to sit there and be a punching bag; I'm going to stand up and say, hey, listen, here's my side of it. Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me. But that's what I feel. That's what I feel passionately about. I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail. How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.  But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --

column1: Excuse me. I don't want to --
I don't want to --
I get wound up because I feel strongly --

Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

My argument with Governor Clinton -- you can call it mud wrestling, but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war. column26: but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war. Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me. But that's what I feel. That's what I feel passionately about. I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail. How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.  But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --

column1: Excuse me. I don't want to --
I don't want to --
I get wound up because I feel strongly --

Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me. But that's what I feel. That's what I feel passionately about. I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail. How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.  But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --

column1: Excuse me. I don't want to --
I don't want to --
I get wound up because I feel strongly --

Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. column1: -- I couldn't agree with you more
column2: couldn't agree with you more. And I have said again and again and again let's get off mud wrestling
column3: let's get off personalities and let's talk about jobs
column4: health care
column6: the things that concern the American people. I'm spending my money -- not PAC money
column7: not foreign money
column8: my money -- to take this message to the people.

column1: Well
column2: in the first place
column3: I believe that character is a part of being president. I think you have to look at it. I think that has to be a part of a candidate for president or being president. In terms of programs
column4: I've submitted
column6: 4 different budgets to the US Congress in great detail. It's so heavy they'd give you a broken back. And everything in there says what I am for. Now I've come out with a new agenda for America's renewal
column7: a plan that I believe really will help stimulate the growth of this economy. My record on world affairs is pretty well known because I've been president for 4 years
column8: so I feel I've been talking issues.  You know
column9: nobody likes who shot John
column10: but I think the first negative campaign run in this election was by Governor Clinton
column11: and I'm not going to sit there and be a punching bag; I'm going to stand up and say
column12: hey
column13: listen
column14: here's my side of it.  But character is an important part of the equation. The other night Governor Clinton raised my -- I don't know if you saw the debate the other night. You did -- suffered through that? Well
column15: he raised the question of my father -- it was a good line
column16: well rehearsed and well delivered. But he raised the question of my father and said
column17: well
column18: your father
column20: was against McCarthy
column21: you should be ashamed of yourself
column22: McCarthyism. I remember something my dad told me -- I was 18 years old going to Penn Station to go on into the Navy
column23: and he said write your mother -- which I faithfully did; he said serve your country -- my father was an honor
column24: duty and country man; and he said tell the truth. And I've tried to do that in public life
column25: all through it. That says something about character.  My argument with Governor Clinton -- you can call it mud wrestling
column26: but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war. Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me. But that's what I feel. That's what I feel passionately about. I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail. How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.  But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --

column1: Excuse me. I don't want to --
I don't want to --
I get wound up because I feel strongly --

Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. column26: but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war. Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me. But that's what I feel. That's what I feel passionately about. I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail. How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.  But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --

column1: Excuse me. I don't want to --
I don't want to --
I get wound up because I feel strongly --

Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times." column2: '15Oct'
column3: 3)	" No
column4: I don't have an answer for everything. As you all know
column5: I've been buying 30-minute segments to talk about issues. And tomorrow night on NBC
column6: from 10:30 to 11 Eastern
column7: we're going to talk about how you pay the debt down
column8: so we're going to come right down to that one. We'll be on again Saturday night
column9: 8 to 9 o'clock on ABC. So the point is --

column1: Like Jerry Brown
column2: the 800 number.

column1: -- I couldn't agree with you more
column2: couldn't agree with you more. And I have said again and again and again let's get off mud wrestling
column3: let's get off personalities and let's talk about jobs
column4: health care
column6: the things that concern the American people. I'm spending my money -- not PAC money
column7: not foreign money
column8: my money -- to take this message to the people.

column1: Well
column2: in the first place
column3: I believe that character is a part of being president. I think you have to look at it. I think that has to be a part of a candidate for president or being president. In terms of programs
column4: I've submitted
column6: 4 different budgets to the US Congress in great detail. It's so heavy they'd give you a broken back. And everything in there says what I am for. Now I've come out with a new agenda for America's renewal
column7: a plan that I believe really will help stimulate the growth of this economy. My record on world affairs is pretty well known because I've been president for 4 years
column8: so I feel I've been talking issues.  You know
column9: nobody likes who shot John
column10: but I think the first negative campaign run in this election was by Governor Clinton
column11: and I'm not going to sit there and be a punching bag; I'm going to stand up and say
column12: hey
column13: listen
column14: here's my side of it.  But character is an important part of the equation. The other night Governor Clinton raised my -- I don't know if you saw the debate the other night. You did -- suffered through that? Well
column15: he raised the question of my father -- it was a good line
column16: well rehearsed and well delivered. But he raised the question of my father and said
column17: well
column18: your father
column20: was against McCarthy
column21: you should be ashamed of yourself
column22: McCarthyism. I remember something my dad told me -- I was 18 years old going to Penn Station to go on into the Navy
column23: and he said write your mother -- which I faithfully did; he said serve your country -- my father was an honor
column24: duty and country man; and he said tell the truth. And I've tried to do that in public life
column25: all through it. That says something about character.  My argument with Governor Clinton -- you can call it mud wrestling
column26: but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war. Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me. But that's what I feel. That's what I feel passionately about. I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail. How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.  But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --

column1: Excuse me. I don't want to --
I don't want to --
I get wound up because I feel strongly --

Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times." column26: but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war. Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me. But that's what I feel. That's what I feel passionately about. I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail. How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.  But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --

column1: Excuse me. I don't want to --
I don't want to --
I get wound up because I feel strongly --

Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year. I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign. Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore. Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase. When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said
column2: that's not true. He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight
column3: but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again. But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote ""political chameleon"" for changing his positions of all times. Now
column4: I don't want to get into that --

column1: Please don't get into the Washington Post.

Wait a minute. Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it. Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.
