column1: I'm not sure that -- and I can understand if you haven't seen this
column2: because there's been a lot of hue and cry. We passed this year the most furthest looking transportation bill in the history of this country since Eisenhower started the interstate highways -- $150 billion for improving the infrastructure. That happened when I was president. And so I'm very proud of the way that came about and I think it's a very
column3: very good beginning. Like Mr. Perot
column4: I am concerned about the deficits and $150 billion is a lot of money
column5: but it's awful hard to say we're going to go out and spend more money when we're trying to get the deficit down. But I would cite that as a major accomplishment. We hear all the negatives. When you're president you expect this. Everybody's running against the incumbent. They can do better. Everyone knows that.  But here's something that we can take great pride in because it really does get to what you're talking about. Our home initiative -- our home ownership initiative -- HOPE -- that passed the Congress is a good start for having people own their own homes instead of living in these deadly tenements.  Our enterprise zones
column6: that we hear a lot of lip service about in Congress
column7: would bring jobs into the inner city. There's a good program. And I need the help of everybody across this country to get it passed in a substantial way by the Congress.  When we went out to south central in Los Angeles -- some of you may remember the riots there. I went out there. I went to a boys' club. And everyone of them -- the boys' club leaders
column8: the ministers -- all of them were saying pass enterprise zones. We go back to Washington and very difficult to get it through the Congress. But there's going to be a new Congress. No one likes gridlock. There's going to be a new Congress because the old one -- I don't want to get this man made at me -- but there was a post office scandal and a bank scandal. You're going to have a lot of new members of Congress. And then you can sit down and say
column9: help me do what we should for the cities. Help me pass these programs.

column1: Sure
column2: but the problem is
column3: you get so many things included in a great big bill that you have to look at the overall good. That's the problem with our system. If you had a line item veto you could knock out the pork. You could knock out the tax increases and you could do what the people want
column4: and that's create enterprise zones.

column1: That bill pays for these urban enterprise zones by asking the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more. And that's why he wants to veto it
column2: just like he vetoed an earlier bill this year. This is not mud slinging. This is fact slinging -- a bill earlier this year. This is facts -- that would have given investment tax credits and other incentives to reinvest in our cities
column3: in our country. But it asked the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more. Mr. Perot wants to do the same thing. I agree with him. I mean
column4: we agree with that. But let me tell you specifically what my plan does. My plan would dedicate $20 billion a year in each of the next 4 years for investments in new transportation
column6: environmental clean-ups and new technologies for the 21st century. And we would target it especially in areas that have been either depressed or which have lost a lot of defense related jobs. There are 200
column7: 000 people in California
column8: for example
column9: who have lost their defense related jobs. They ought to be engaged in making high speed rail. They ought to be engaged in breaking ground in other technologies
column10: doing waste recycling
column11: clean water technology and things of that kind.  We can create millions of jobs in these new technologies- -more than we're going to lose in defense -- if we target it. But we're investing a much smaller percentage of our income in the things you just asked about than all of our major competitors
column12: and our wealth growth is going down as a result of it. It's making the country poorer
column13: which is why I answered the gentleman the way I did before. We have to both bring down the deficit and get our economy going through these kinds of investments in order to get the kind of wealth and jobs and incomes we need in America.

column1: First you've got to have money to pay for these things. So you've got to create jobs. There are all kinds of ways to create jobs in the inner city. I'm not a politician
column2: but I think I could go to Washington in a week and get everybody holding hands and get this bill signed because I talk to the Democratic leaders and they want it. I talk to the Republican leaders and they want it. But since they're bred from childhood to fight with one another rather than get results
column3: you know
column4: I would be glad to drop out and spend a little time and see if we couldn't build some bridges. Now
column5: results is what counts. The president can't order Congress around. Congress can't order the president around. That's not bad for a guy that's never been there
column6: right? But you have to work together.  Now
column7: I have talked to the chairmen of the committees that want this. They're Democrats. The president wants it
column8: but we can't get it because we sit here in gridlock because it's a campaign year. We didn't fund a lot of other things this year
column9: like the savings and loan mess. That's another story that we're going to pay a big price for right after the election.  The facts are though -- the facts are -- the American people are hurting. These people are hurting in the inner cities. We're shipping the quote
column10: ""low paying jobs"" overseas. What are low paying jobs? Textiles
column11: shoes
column12: things like that that we say are yesterday's industries. They're tomorrow's industries in the inner cities.  Let me say in my case
column13: if I'm out of work
column14: I'll cut grass tomorrow to take care of my family; I'll be happy to make shoes
column15: I'll be happy to make clothing
column16: I'll make sausage. You just give me a job. Put those jobs in the inner cities instead of doing diplomatic deals and shipping them to China where prison labor does the work.

column1: I'm not sure that -- and I can understand if you haven't seen this
column2: because there's been a lot of hue and cry. We passed this year the most furthest looking transportation bill in the history of this country since Eisenhower started the interstate highways -- $150 billion for improving the infrastructure. That happened when I was president. And so I'm very proud of the way that came about and I think it's a very
column3: very good beginning. Like Mr. Perot
column4: I am concerned about the deficits and $150 billion is a lot of money
column5: but it's awful hard to say we're going to go out and spend more money when we're trying to get the deficit down. But I would cite that as a major accomplishment. We hear all the negatives. When you're president you expect this. Everybody's running against the incumbent. They can do better. Everyone knows that.  But here's something that we can take great pride in because it really does get to what you're talking about. Our home initiative -- our home ownership initiative -- HOPE -- that passed the Congress is a good start for having people own their own homes instead of living in these deadly tenements.  Our enterprise zones
column6: that we hear a lot of lip service about in Congress
column7: would bring jobs into the inner city. There's a good program. And I need the help of everybody across this country to get it passed in a substantial way by the Congress.  When we went out to south central in Los Angeles -- some of you may remember the riots there. I went out there. I went to a boys' club. And everyone of them -- the boys' club leaders
column8: the ministers -- all of them were saying pass enterprise zones. We go back to Washington and very difficult to get it through the Congress. But there's going to be a new Congress. No one likes gridlock. There's going to be a new Congress because the old one -- I don't want to get this man made at me -- but there was a post office scandal and a bank scandal. You're going to have a lot of new members of Congress. And then you can sit down and say
column9: help me do what we should for the cities. Help me pass these programs.

column4: and that's create enterprise zones.

column1: That bill pays for these urban enterprise zones by asking the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more. And that's why he wants to veto it
column2: just like he vetoed an earlier bill this year. This is not mud slinging. This is fact slinging -- a bill earlier this year. This is facts -- that would have given investment tax credits and other incentives to reinvest in our cities
column3: in our country. But it asked the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more. Mr. Perot wants to do the same thing. I agree with him. I mean
column4: we agree with that. But let me tell you specifically what my plan does. My plan would dedicate $20 billion a year in each of the next 4 years for investments in new transportation
column6: environmental clean-ups and new technologies for the 21st century. And we would target it especially in areas that have been either depressed or which have lost a lot of defense related jobs. There are 200
column7: 000 people in California
column8: for example
column9: who have lost their defense related jobs. They ought to be engaged in making high speed rail. They ought to be engaged in breaking ground in other technologies
column10: doing waste recycling
column11: clean water technology and things of that kind.  We can create millions of jobs in these new technologies- -more than we're going to lose in defense -- if we target it. But we're investing a much smaller percentage of our income in the things you just asked about than all of our major competitors
column12: and our wealth growth is going down as a result of it. It's making the country poorer
column13: which is why I answered the gentleman the way I did before. We have to both bring down the deficit and get our economy going through these kinds of investments in order to get the kind of wealth and jobs and incomes we need in America.

column1: I'm not sure that -- and I can understand if you haven't seen this
column2: because there's been a lot of hue and cry. We passed this year the most furthest looking transportation bill in the history of this country since Eisenhower started the interstate highways -- $150 billion for improving the infrastructure. That happened when I was president. And so I'm very proud of the way that came about and I think it's a very
column3: very good beginning. Like Mr. Perot
column4: I am concerned about the deficits and $150 billion is a lot of money
column5: but it's awful hard to say we're going to go out and spend more money when we're trying to get the deficit down. But I would cite that as a major accomplishment. We hear all the negatives. When you're president you expect this. Everybody's running against the incumbent. They can do better. Everyone knows that.  But here's something that we can take great pride in because it really does get to what you're talking about. Our home initiative -- our home ownership initiative -- HOPE -- that passed the Congress is a good start for having people own their own homes instead of living in these deadly tenements.  Our enterprise zones
column6: that we hear a lot of lip service about in Congress
column7: would bring jobs into the inner city. There's a good program. And I need the help of everybody across this country to get it passed in a substantial way by the Congress.  When we went out to south central in Los Angeles -- some of you may remember the riots there. I went out there. I went to a boys' club. And everyone of them -- the boys' club leaders
column8: the ministers -- all of them were saying pass enterprise zones. We go back to Washington and very difficult to get it through the Congress. But there's going to be a new Congress. No one likes gridlock. There's going to be a new Congress because the old one -- I don't want to get this man made at me -- but there was a post office scandal and a bank scandal. You're going to have a lot of new members of Congress. And then you can sit down and say
column9: help me do what we should for the cities. Help me pass these programs.

column1: Sure
column2: but the problem is
column3: you get so many things included in a great big bill that you have to look at the overall good. That's the problem with our system. If you had a line item veto you could knock out the pork. You could knock out the tax increases and you could do what the people want
column4: and that's create enterprise zones.

column1: That bill pays for these urban enterprise zones by asking the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more. And that's why he wants to veto it
column2: just like he vetoed an earlier bill this year. This is not mud slinging. This is fact slinging -- a bill earlier this year. This is facts -- that would have given investment tax credits and other incentives to reinvest in our cities
column3: in our country. But it asked the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more. Mr. Perot wants to do the same thing. I agree with him. I mean
column4: we agree with that. But let me tell you specifically what my plan does. My plan would dedicate $20 billion a year in each of the next 4 years for investments in new transportation
column6: environmental clean-ups and new technologies for the 21st century. And we would target it especially in areas that have been either depressed or which have lost a lot of defense related jobs. There are 200
column7: 000 people in California
column8: for example
column9: who have lost their defense related jobs. They ought to be engaged in making high speed rail. They ought to be engaged in breaking ground in other technologies
column10: doing waste recycling
column11: clean water technology and things of that kind.  We can create millions of jobs in these new technologies- -more than we're going to lose in defense -- if we target it. But we're investing a much smaller percentage of our income in the things you just asked about than all of our major competitors
column12: and our wealth growth is going down as a result of it. It's making the country poorer
column13: which is why I answered the gentleman the way I did before. We have to both bring down the deficit and get our economy going through these kinds of investments in order to get the kind of wealth and jobs and incomes we need in America.

column1: First you've got to have money to pay for these things. So you've got to create jobs. There are all kinds of ways to create jobs in the inner city. I'm not a politician
column2: but I think I could go to Washington in a week and get everybody holding hands and get this bill signed because I talk to the Democratic leaders and they want it. I talk to the Republican leaders and they want it. But since they're bred from childhood to fight with one another rather than get results
column3: you know
column4: I would be glad to drop out and spend a little time and see if we couldn't build some bridges. Now
column5: results is what counts. The president can't order Congress around. Congress can't order the president around. That's not bad for a guy that's never been there
column6: right? But you have to work together.  Now
column7: I have talked to the chairmen of the committees that want this. They're Democrats. The president wants it
column8: but we can't get it because we sit here in gridlock because it's a campaign year. We didn't fund a lot of other things this year
column9: like the savings and loan mess. That's another story that we're going to pay a big price for right after the election.  The facts are though -- the facts are -- the American people are hurting. These people are hurting in the inner cities. We're shipping the quote
column10: ""low paying jobs"" overseas. What are low paying jobs? Textiles
column11: shoes
column12: things like that that we say are yesterday's industries. They're tomorrow's industries in the inner cities.  Let me say in my case
column13: if I'm out of work
column14: I'll cut grass tomorrow to take care of my family; I'll be happy to make shoes
column15: I'll be happy to make clothing
column16: I'll make sausage. You just give me a job. Put those jobs in the inner cities instead of doing diplomatic deals and shipping them to China where prison labor does the work.

column1: If you ask me if I could fly a fighter plane or be an astronaut
column2: I can't. I've spent my life creating jobs. That's something I know how to do. And
column3: very simply
column4: in the inner city
column6: small business is the way to jump start the inner city
column7: not --

column1: You want jobs in the inner city? Do you want jobs in the inner city? Is that your question?
Oh
column2: I'm sorry. Well
column3: I've listened to both sides
column4: and if they would talk to one another instead of throwing rocks
column5: I think we could get a lot done. And
column6: among other things
column7: I would say
column8: okay
column9: over here in this Senate committee to the chairman who is anxious to get this bill passed
column10: the president who is anxious
column11: I'd say rather than just yelling at one another
column12: why don't we find out where we're apart
column13: try to get together
column14: get the bill passed and give the people the benefits and not play party politics right now. And I think the press would follow that so closely that probably they would get it done. That's the way I would do it. I doubt if they'll give me the chance
column15: but I will drop everything and go work on it.

column1: I'm not sure that -- and I can understand if you haven't seen this
column2: because there's been a lot of hue and cry. We passed this year the most furthest looking transportation bill in the history of this country since Eisenhower started the interstate highways -- $150 billion for improving the infrastructure. That happened when I was president. And so I'm very proud of the way that came about and I think it's a very
column3: very good beginning. Like Mr. Perot
column4: I am concerned about the deficits and $150 billion is a lot of money
column5: but it's awful hard to say we're going to go out and spend more money when we're trying to get the deficit down. But I would cite that as a major accomplishment. We hear all the negatives. When you're president you expect this. Everybody's running against the incumbent. They can do better. Everyone knows that.  But here's something that we can take great pride in because it really does get to what you're talking about. Our home initiative -- our home ownership initiative -- HOPE -- that passed the Congress is a good start for having people own their own homes instead of living in these deadly tenements.  Our enterprise zones
column6: that we hear a lot of lip service about in Congress
column7: would bring jobs into the inner city. There's a good program. And I need the help of everybody across this country to get it passed in a substantial way by the Congress.  When we went out to south central in Los Angeles -- some of you may remember the riots there. I went out there. I went to a boys' club. And everyone of them -- the boys' club leaders
column8: the ministers -- all of them were saying pass enterprise zones. We go back to Washington and very difficult to get it through the Congress. But there's going to be a new Congress. No one likes gridlock. There's going to be a new Congress because the old one -- I don't want to get this man made at me -- but there was a post office scandal and a bank scandal. You're going to have a lot of new members of Congress. And then you can sit down and say
column9: help me do what we should for the cities. Help me pass these programs.

column1: Sure
column2: but the problem is
column3: you get so many things included in a great big bill that you have to look at the overall good. That's the problem with our system. If you had a line item veto you could knock out the pork. You could knock out the tax increases and you could do what the people want
column4: and that's create enterprise zones.

column1: That bill pays for these urban enterprise zones by asking the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more. And that's why he wants to veto it
column2: just like he vetoed an earlier bill this year. This is not mud slinging. This is fact slinging -- a bill earlier this year. This is facts -- that would have given investment tax credits and other incentives to reinvest in our cities
column3: in our country. But it asked the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more. Mr. Perot wants to do the same thing. I agree with him. I mean
column4: we agree with that. But let me tell you specifically what my plan does. My plan would dedicate $20 billion a year in each of the next 4 years for investments in new transportation
column6: environmental clean-ups and new technologies for the 21st century. And we would target it especially in areas that have been either depressed or which have lost a lot of defense related jobs. There are 200
column7: 000 people in California
column8: for example
column9: who have lost their defense related jobs. They ought to be engaged in making high speed rail. They ought to be engaged in breaking ground in other technologies
column10: doing waste recycling
column11: clean water technology and things of that kind.  We can create millions of jobs in these new technologies- -more than we're going to lose in defense -- if we target it. But we're investing a much smaller percentage of our income in the things you just asked about than all of our major competitors
column12: and our wealth growth is going down as a result of it. It's making the country poorer
column13: which is why I answered the gentleman the way I did before. We have to both bring down the deficit and get our economy going through these kinds of investments in order to get the kind of wealth and jobs and incomes we need in America.

column1: First you've got to have money to pay for these things. So you've got to create jobs. There are all kinds of ways to create jobs in the inner city. I'm not a politician
column2: but I think I could go to Washington in a week and get everybody holding hands and get this bill signed because I talk to the Democratic leaders and they want it. I talk to the Republican leaders and they want it. But since they're bred from childhood to fight with one another rather than get results
column3: you know
column4: I would be glad to drop out and spend a little time and see if we couldn't build some bridges. Now
column5: results is what counts. The president can't order Congress around. Congress can't order the president around. That's not bad for a guy that's never been there
column6: right? But you have to work together.  Now
column7: I have talked to the chairmen of the committees that want this. They're Democrats. The president wants it
column8: but we can't get it because we sit here in gridlock because it's a campaign year. We didn't fund a lot of other things this year
column9: like the savings and loan mess. That's another story that we're going to pay a big price for right after the election.  The facts are though -- the facts are -- the American people are hurting. These people are hurting in the inner cities. We're shipping the quote
column10: ""low paying jobs"" overseas. What are low paying jobs? Textiles
column11: shoes
column12: things like that that we say are yesterday's industries. They're tomorrow's industries in the inner cities.  Let me say in my case
column13: if I'm out of work
column14: I'll cut grass tomorrow to take care of my family; I'll be happy to make shoes
column15: I'll be happy to make clothing
column16: I'll make sausage. You just give me a job. Put those jobs in the inner cities instead of doing diplomatic deals and shipping them to China where prison labor does the work.

column1: I'm not sure that -- and I can understand if you haven't seen this
column2: because there's been a lot of hue and cry. We passed this year the most furthest looking transportation bill in the history of this country since Eisenhower started the interstate highways -- $150 billion for improving the infrastructure. That happened when I was president. And so I'm very proud of the way that came about and I think it's a very
column3: very good beginning. Like Mr. Perot
column4: I am concerned about the deficits and $150 billion is a lot of money
column5: but it's awful hard to say we're going to go out and spend more money when we're trying to get the deficit down. But I would cite that as a major accomplishment. We hear all the negatives. When you're president you expect this. Everybody's running against the incumbent. They can do better. Everyone knows that.  But here's something that we can take great pride in because it really does get to what you're talking about. Our home initiative -- our home ownership initiative -- HOPE -- that passed the Congress is a good start for having people own their own homes instead of living in these deadly tenements.  Our enterprise zones
column6: that we hear a lot of lip service about in Congress
column7: would bring jobs into the inner city. There's a good program. And I need the help of everybody across this country to get it passed in a substantial way by the Congress.  When we went out to south central in Los Angeles -- some of you may remember the riots there. I went out there. I went to a boys' club. And everyone of them -- the boys' club leaders
column8: the ministers -- all of them were saying pass enterprise zones. We go back to Washington and very difficult to get it through the Congress. But there's going to be a new Congress. No one likes gridlock. There's going to be a new Congress because the old one -- I don't want to get this man made at me -- but there was a post office scandal and a bank scandal. You're going to have a lot of new members of Congress. And then you can sit down and say
column9: help me do what we should for the cities. Help me pass these programs.

column1: Sure
column2: but the problem is
column3: you get so many things included in a great big bill that you have to look at the overall good. That's the problem with our system. If you had a line item veto you could knock out the pork. You could knock out the tax increases and you could do what the people want
column4: and that's create enterprise zones.

column1: That bill pays for these urban enterprise zones by asking the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more. And that's why he wants to veto it
column2: just like he vetoed an earlier bill this year. This is not mud slinging. This is fact slinging -- a bill earlier this year. This is facts -- that would have given investment tax credits and other incentives to reinvest in our cities
column3: in our country. But it asked the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more. Mr. Perot wants to do the same thing. I agree with him. I mean
column4: we agree with that. But let me tell you specifically what my plan does. My plan would dedicate $20 billion a year in each of the next 4 years for investments in new transportation
column6: environmental clean-ups and new technologies for the 21st century. And we would target it especially in areas that have been either depressed or which have lost a lot of defense related jobs. There are 200
column7: 000 people in California
column8: for example
column9: who have lost their defense related jobs. They ought to be engaged in making high speed rail. They ought to be engaged in breaking ground in other technologies
column10: doing waste recycling
column11: clean water technology and things of that kind.  We can create millions of jobs in these new technologies- -more than we're going to lose in defense -- if we target it. But we're investing a much smaller percentage of our income in the things you just asked about than all of our major competitors
column12: and our wealth growth is going down as a result of it. It's making the country poorer
column13: which is why I answered the gentleman the way I did before. We have to both bring down the deficit and get our economy going through these kinds of investments in order to get the kind of wealth and jobs and incomes we need in America.

column1: First you've got to have money to pay for these things. So you've got to create jobs. There are all kinds of ways to create jobs in the inner city. I'm not a politician
column2: but I think I could go to Washington in a week and get everybody holding hands and get this bill signed because I talk to the Democratic leaders and they want it. I talk to the Republican leaders and they want it. But since they're bred from childhood to fight with one another rather than get results
column3: you know
column4: I would be glad to drop out and spend a little time and see if we couldn't build some bridges. Now
column5: results is what counts. The president can't order Congress around. Congress can't order the president around. That's not bad for a guy that's never been there
column6: right? But you have to work together.  Now
column7: I have talked to the chairmen of the committees that want this. They're Democrats. The president wants it
column8: but we can't get it because we sit here in gridlock because it's a campaign year. We didn't fund a lot of other things this year
column9: like the savings and loan mess. That's another story that we're going to pay a big price for right after the election.  The facts are though -- the facts are -- the American people are hurting. These people are hurting in the inner cities. We're shipping the quote
column10: ""low paying jobs"" overseas. What are low paying jobs? Textiles
column11: shoes
column12: things like that that we say are yesterday's industries. They're tomorrow's industries in the inner cities.  Let me say in my case
column13: if I'm out of work
column14: I'll cut grass tomorrow to take care of my family; I'll be happy to make shoes
column15: I'll be happy to make clothing
column16: I'll make sausage. You just give me a job. Put those jobs in the inner cities instead of doing diplomatic deals and shipping them to China where prison labor does the work.

column3: very good beginning. Like Mr. Perot
column4: I am concerned about the deficits and $150 billion is a lot of money
column5: but it's awful hard to say we're going to go out and spend more money when we're trying to get the deficit down. But I would cite that as a major accomplishment. We hear all the negatives. When you're president you expect this. Everybody's running against the incumbent. They can do better. Everyone knows that.  But here's something that we can take great pride in because it really does get to what you're talking about. Our home initiative -- our home ownership initiative -- HOPE -- that passed the Congress is a good start for having people own their own homes instead of living in these deadly tenements.  Our enterprise zones
column6: that we hear a lot of lip service about in Congress
column7: would bring jobs into the inner city. There's a good program. And I need the help of everybody across this country to get it passed in a substantial way by the Congress.  When we went out to south central in Los Angeles -- some of you may remember the riots there. I went out there. I went to a boys' club. And everyone of them -- the boys' club leaders
column8: the ministers -- all of them were saying pass enterprise zones. We go back to Washington and very difficult to get it through the Congress. But there's going to be a new Congress. No one likes gridlock. There's going to be a new Congress because the old one -- I don't want to get this man made at me -- but there was a post office scandal and a bank scandal. You're going to have a lot of new members of Congress. And then you can sit down and say
column9: help me do what we should for the cities. Help me pass these programs.

column4: we agree with that. But let me tell you specifically what my plan does. My plan would dedicate $20 billion a year in each of the next 4 years for investments in new transportation
column6: environmental clean-ups and new technologies for the 21st century. And we would target it especially in areas that have been either depressed or which have lost a lot of defense related jobs. There are 200
column7: 000 people in California

column9: who have lost their defense related jobs. They ought to be engaged in making high speed rail. They ought to be engaged in breaking ground in other technologies
column10: doing waste recycling
column11: clean water technology and things of that kind.  We can create millions of jobs in these new technologies- -more than we're going to lose in defense -- if we target it. column12: and our wealth growth is going down as a result of it. It's making the country poorer
column13: which is why I answered the gentleman the way I did before. We have to both bring down the deficit and get our economy going through these kinds of investments in order to get the kind of wealth and jobs and incomes we need in America.

column3: 6)	" I support the right to keep and bear arms. I live in a state where over half the adults have hunting or fishing licenses
column4: or both. But I believe we have to have some way of checking hand guns before they're sold
column6: the mental health history
column7: and the age of people who are buying them. Therefore I support the Brady bill which would impose a national waiting period unless and until a state did what only Virginia has done now
column8: which is to automate its records. Once you automate your records
column9: then you don't have to have a waiting period
column10: but at least you can check. I also think we should have frankly restrictions on assault weapons whose only purpose is to kill. We need to give the police a fighting chance in our urban areas where the gangs are building up.  The third thing I would say -- it doesn't bear directly on gun control
column11: but it's very important -- we need more police on the street. There is a crime bill which would put more police on the street
column12: which was killed for this session by a filibuster in the Senate
column13: mostly be Republican senators
column14: and I think it's a shame it didn't pass
column15: I think it should be made the law -- but it had the Brady bill in it
column16: the waiting period.  I also believe that we should offer college scholarships to people who will agree to work them off as police officers
column17: and I think
column18: as we reduce our military forces
column19: we should let people earn military retirement by coming out and working as police officers. Thirty years ago there were three police officers on the street for every crime; today there are three crimes for every police officer.  In the communities which have had real success putting police officers near schools where kids carry weapons
column20: to get the weapons out of the schools
column21: are on the same blocks
column22: you've seen crime go down. In Houston there's been a 15- percent drop in the crime rate in the last year because of the work the mayor did there in increasing the police force. So I know it can work; I've seen it happen.

column1: I think you put your finger on a major problem. I talk about strengthening the American family and it's very hard to strengthen the family if people are scared to walk down to the corner store and
column2: you know
column3: send their kid down to get a loaf of bread. It's very hard. I have been fighting for very strong anti-crime legislation -- habeas corpus reform
column4: so you don't have these endless appeals
column6: hey
column7: this is for real. I've been fighting for changes in the exclusionary rule so if an honest cop stops somebody and makes a technical mistake
column8: the criminal doesn't go away.  I'll probably get into a fight in this room with some but I happen to think that we need stronger death penalties for those that kill police officers.  Virginia's in the lead in this
column9: as Governor Clinton properly said
column10: on this identification system for firearms. I am not for national registration of firearms. Some of the states that have the toughest anti-gun laws have the highest levels of crime. I am for the right
column11: as the governor says- -I'm a sportsman and I don't think you ought to eliminate all kinds of weapons. But I was not for the bill that he was talking about because it was not tough enough on the criminal.  I'm very pleased that the Fraternal Order of Police in Little Rock
column12: Arkansas endorsed me because I think they see I'm trying to strengthen the anti-crime legislation. We've got more money going out for local police than any previous administration.  So we've got to get it under control and there's one last point I'd make. Drugs. We have got to win our national strategy against drugs
column13: the fight against drugs. And we're making some progress
column14: doing a little better on interdiction. We're not doing as well amongst the people that get to be habitual drug-users.  The good news is
column15: and I think it's true in Richmond
column16: teenage use is down of cocaine
column17: substantially
column18: 60% in the last couple of years. So we're making progress but until we get that one done

column6: you name it. Brady Bill
column7: I agree that it's a timid step in the right direction but it won't fix it. So why pass a law that won't fix it? Now
column8: what it really boils down to is can you live -- we become so preoccupied with the rights of the criminal that we've forgotten the rights of the innocent. And in our country we have evolved to a point where we've put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and they've put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately. That's where we are. We have got to become more concerned about people who play by the rules and get the balance we require. This is going to take first
column9: building a consensus at grassroots America. Right from the bottom up
column10: the American people have got to say they want it. And at that point
column11: we can pick from a variety of plans and develop new plans. And the way you get things done is bury yourselves in the room with one another
column12: put together the best program
column13: take it to the American people
column14: use the electronic town hall
column15: the kind of thing you're doing here tonight

1969.44']	['I support the right to keep and bear arms', 'I live in a state where over half the adults have hunting or fishing licenses, or both', 'But I believe we have to have some way of checking hand guns before theyre sold, to check the criminal history, the mental health history, and the age of people who are buying them', 'Therefore I support the Brady bill which would impose a national waiting period unless and until a state did what only Virginia has done now, which is to automate its records', 'Once you automate your records, then you dont have to have a waiting period, but at least you can check', 'I also think we should have frankly restrictions on assault weapons whose only purpose is to kill', 'We need to give the police a fighting chance in our urban areas where the gangs are building up', 'The third thing I would say  it doesnt bear directly on gun control, but its very important  we need more police on the street', 'There is a crime bill which would put more police on the street, which was killed for this session by a filibuster in the Senate, mostly be Republican senators, and I think its a shame it didnt pass, I think it should be made the law  but it had the Brady bill in it, the waiting period', 'I also believe that we should offer college scholarships to people who will agree to work them off as police officers, and I think, as we reduce our military forces, we should let people earn military retirement by coming out and working as police officers', 'Thirty years ago there were three police officers on the street for every crime; today there are three crimes for every police officer', 'In the communities which have had real success putting police officers near schools where kids carry weapons, to get the weapons out of the schools, are on the same blocks, youve seen crime go down', 'In Houston theres been a 15 percent drop in the crime rate in the last year because of the work the mayor did there in increasing the police force', 'So I know it can work; Ive seen it happen', 'I think you put your finger on a major problem', 'I talk about strengthening the American family and its very hard to strengthen the family if people are scared to walk down to the corner store and, you know, send their kid down to get a loaf of bread', 'Its very hard', 'I have been fighting for very strong anticrime legislation  habeas corpus reform, so you dont have these endless appeals, so when somebody gets sentenced, hey, this is for real', 'Ive been fighting for changes in the exclusionary rule so if an honest cop stops somebody and makes a technical mistake, the criminal doesnt go away', 'Ill probably get into a fight in this room with some but I happen to think that we need stronger death penalties for those that kill police officers', 'Virginias in the lead in this, as Governor Clinton properly said, on this identification system for firearms', 'I am not for national registration of firearms', 'Some of the states that have the toughest antigun laws have the highest levels of crime', 'I am for the right, as the governor says Im a sportsman and I dont think you ought to eliminate all kinds of weapons', 'But I was not for the bill that he was talking about because it was not tough enough on the criminal', 'Im very pleased that the Fraternal Order of Police in Little Rock, Arkansas endorsed me because I think they see Im trying to strengthen the anticrime legislation', 'Weve got more money going out for local police than any previous administration', 'So weve got to get it under control and theres one last point Id make', 'Drugs', 'We have got to win our national strategy against drugs, the fight against drugs', 'And were making some progress, doing a little better on interdiction', 'Were not doing as well amongst the people that get to be habitual drugusers', 'The good news is, and I think its true in Richmond, teenage use is down of cocaine, substantially, 60% in the last couple of years', 'So were making progress but until we get that one done, were not going to solve the neighborhood crime problem', 'I didnt get to make a comment on this', 'Oh, youre going to let me', 'Excuse me', 'On any program, and this includes crime, youll find we have all kinds of great plans lying around that never get enacted into law and implemented', 'I dont care what it is  competitiveness, health care, crime, you name it', 'Brady Bill, I agree that its a timid step in the right direction but it wont fix it', 'So why pass a law that wont fix it?', 'Now, what it really boils down to is can you live  we become so preoccupied with the rights of the criminal that weve forgotten the rights of the innocent', 'And in our country we have evolved to a point where weve put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and theyve put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately', 'Thats where we are', 'We have got to become more concerned about people who play by the rules and get the balance we require', 'This is going to take first, building a consensus at grassroots America', 'Right from the bottom up, the American people have got to say they want it', 'And at that point, we can pick from a variety of plans and develop new plans', 'And the way you get things done is bury yourselves in the room with one another, put together the best program, take it to the American people, use the electronic town hall, the kind of thing youre doing here tonight, build a consensus and then do it and then go on to the next one', 'But dont just sit here slow dancing for 4 years doing nothing']	['I support the right to keep and bear arms.'

column4: or both. But I believe we have to have some way of checking hand guns before they're sold
column6: the mental health history
column7: and the age of people who are buying them. Therefore I support the Brady bill which would impose a national waiting period unless and until a state did what only Virginia has done now
column8: which is to automate its records. Once you automate your records
column9: then you don't have to have a waiting period
column10: but at least you can check. I also think we should have frankly restrictions on assault weapons whose only purpose is to kill. We need to give the police a fighting chance in our urban areas where the gangs are building up.  The third thing I would say -- it doesn't bear directly on gun control
column11: but it's very important -- we need more police on the street. There is a crime bill which would put more police on the street
column12: which was killed for this session by a filibuster in the Senate
column13: mostly be Republican senators
column14: and I think it's a shame it didn't pass

column17: and I think
column18: as we reduce our military forces
column19: we should let people earn military retirement by coming out and working as police officers. Thirty years ago there were three police officers on the street for every crime; today there are three crimes for every police officer.  In the communities which have had real success putting police officers near schools where kids carry weapons
column20: to get the weapons out of the schools

column22: you've seen crime go down. In Houston there's been a 15- percent drop in the crime rate in the last year because of the work the mayor did there in increasing the police force. So I know it can work; I've seen it happen.

column1: I think you put your finger on a major problem. I talk about strengthening the American family and it's very hard to strengthen the family if people are scared to walk down to the corner store and
column2: you know
column3: send their kid down to get a loaf of bread. It's very hard. I have been fighting for very strong anti-crime legislation -- habeas corpus reform
column4: so you don't have these endless appeals
column6: hey
column7: this is for real. I've been fighting for changes in the exclusionary rule so if an honest cop stops somebody and makes a technical mistake
column8: the criminal doesn't go away.  I'll probably get into a fight in this room with some but I happen to think that we need stronger death penalties for those that kill police officers.  Virginia's in the lead in this
column9: as Governor Clinton properly said
column10: on this identification system for firearms. I am not for national registration of firearms. Some of the states that have the toughest anti-gun laws have the highest levels of crime. I am for the right
column11: as the governor says- -I'm a sportsman and I don't think you ought to eliminate all kinds of weapons. But I was not for the bill that he was talking about because it was not tough enough on the criminal.  I'm very pleased that the Fraternal Order of Police in Little Rock
column12: Arkansas endorsed me because I think they see I'm trying to strengthen the anti-crime legislation. We've got more money going out for local police than any previous administration.  So we've got to get it under control and there's one last point I'd make. Drugs. We have got to win our national strategy against drugs
column13: the fight against drugs. And we're making some progress
column14: doing a little better on interdiction. We're not doing as well amongst the people that get to be habitual drug-users.  The good news is
column15: and I think it's true in Richmond
column16: teenage use is down of cocaine
column17: substantially
column18: 60% in the last couple of years. So we're making progress but until we get that one done
column19: we're not going to solve the neighborhood crime problem.

column1: On any program
column2: and this includes crime
column3: you'll find we have all kinds of great plans lying around that never get enacted into law and implemented. I don't care what it is -- competitiveness
column4: health care
column6: you name it. Brady Bill
column7: I agree that it's a timid step in the right direction but it won't fix it. So why pass a law that won't fix it? Now
column8: what it really boils down to is can you live -- we become so preoccupied with the rights of the criminal that we've forgotten the rights of the innocent. And in our country we have evolved to a point where we've put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and they've put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately. That's where we are. We have got to become more concerned about people who play by the rules and get the balance we require. This is going to take first
column9: building a consensus at grassroots America. Right from the bottom up
column10: the American people have got to say they want it. And at that point
column11: we can pick from a variety of plans and develop new plans. And the way you get things done is bury yourselves in the room with one another
column12: put together the best program
column13: take it to the American people
column14: use the electronic town hall
column15: the kind of thing you're doing here tonight
column16: build a consensus and then do it and then go on to the next one. But don't just sit here slow dancing for 4 years doing nothing.

column3: 6)	" I support the right to keep and bear arms. I live in a state where over half the adults have hunting or fishing licenses
column4: or both. But I believe we have to have some way of checking hand guns before they're sold
column6: the mental health history
column7: and the age of people who are buying them. Therefore I support the Brady bill which would impose a national waiting period unless and until a state did what only Virginia has done now
column8: which is to automate its records. Once you automate your records
column9: then you don't have to have a waiting period
column10: but at least you can check. I also think we should have frankly restrictions on assault weapons whose only purpose is to kill. We need to give the police a fighting chance in our urban areas where the gangs are building up.  The third thing I would say -- it doesn't bear directly on gun control
column11: but it's very important -- we need more police on the street. There is a crime bill which would put more police on the street
column12: which was killed for this session by a filibuster in the Senate
column13: mostly be Republican senators
column14: and I think it's a shame it didn't pass
column15: I think it should be made the law -- but it had the Brady bill in it
column16: the waiting period.  I also believe that we should offer college scholarships to people who will agree to work them off as police officers
column17: and I think
column18: as we reduce our military forces
column19: we should let people earn military retirement by coming out and working as police officers. Thirty years ago there were three police officers on the street for every crime; today there are three crimes for every police officer. column20: to get the weapons out of the schools

column1: I think you put your finger on a major problem. I talk about strengthening the American family and it's very hard to strengthen the family if people are scared to walk down to the corner store and
column2: you know
column3: send their kid down to get a loaf of bread. It's very hard. I have been fighting for very strong anti-crime legislation -- habeas corpus reform
column4: so you don't have these endless appeals
column6: hey
column7: this is for real. I've been fighting for changes in the exclusionary rule so if an honest cop stops somebody and makes a technical mistake
column8: the criminal doesn't go away.  I'll probably get into a fight in this room with some but I happen to think that we need stronger death penalties for those that kill police officers.  Virginia's in the lead in this
column9: as Governor Clinton properly said
column10: on this identification system for firearms. I am not for national registration of firearms. Some of the states that have the toughest anti-gun laws have the highest levels of crime. I am for the right
column11: as the governor says- -I'm a sportsman and I don't think you ought to eliminate all kinds of weapons. But I was not for the bill that he was talking about because it was not tough enough on the criminal.  I'm very pleased that the Fraternal Order of Police in Little Rock
column12: Arkansas endorsed me because I think they see I'm trying to strengthen the anti-crime legislation. We've got more money going out for local police than any previous administration.  So we've got to get it under control and there's one last point I'd make. Drugs. We have got to win our national strategy against drugs
column13: the fight against drugs. And we're making some progress
column14: doing a little better on interdiction. We're not doing as well amongst the people that get to be habitual drug-users.  The good news is
column15: and I think it's true in Richmond
column16: teenage use is down of cocaine
column17: substantially
column18: 60% in the last couple of years. So we're making progress but until we get that one done
column19: we're not going to solve the neighborhood crime problem.

column1: On any program
column2: and this includes crime
column3: you'll find we have all kinds of great plans lying around that never get enacted into law and implemented. I don't care what it is -- competitiveness
column4: health care
column6: you name it. Brady Bill
column7: I agree that it's a timid step in the right direction but it won't fix it. So why pass a law that won't fix it? Now
column8: what it really boils down to is can you live -- we become so preoccupied with the rights of the criminal that we've forgotten the rights of the innocent. And in our country we have evolved to a point where we've put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and they've put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately. That's where we are. We have got to become more concerned about people who play by the rules and get the balance we require. This is going to take first
column9: building a consensus at grassroots America. Right from the bottom up
column10: the American people have got to say they want it. And at that point
column11: we can pick from a variety of plans and develop new plans. And the way you get things done is bury yourselves in the room with one another
column12: put together the best program
column13: take it to the American people
column14: use the electronic town hall
column15: the kind of thing you're doing here tonight
column16: build a consensus and then do it and then go on to the next one. But don't just sit here slow dancing for 4 years doing nothing.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 6)	" I support the right to keep and bear arms. I live in a state where over half the adults have hunting or fishing licenses
column4: or both. But I believe we have to have some way of checking hand guns before they're sold
column6: the mental health history
column7: and the age of people who are buying them. Therefore I support the Brady bill which would impose a national waiting period unless and until a state did what only Virginia has done now
column8: which is to automate its records. Once you automate your records
column9: then you don't have to have a waiting period
column10: but at least you can check. I also think we should have frankly restrictions on assault weapons whose only purpose is to kill. We need to give the police a fighting chance in our urban areas where the gangs are building up.  The third thing I would say -- it doesn't bear directly on gun control
column11: but it's very important -- we need more police on the street. There is a crime bill which would put more police on the street
column12: which was killed for this session by a filibuster in the Senate
column13: mostly be Republican senators
column14: and I think it's a shame it didn't pass
column15: I think it should be made the law -- but it had the Brady bill in it
column16: the waiting period.  I also believe that we should offer college scholarships to people who will agree to work them off as police officers
column17: and I think
column18: as we reduce our military forces
column19: we should let people earn military retirement by coming out and working as police officers. Thirty years ago there were three police officers on the street for every crime; today there are three crimes for every police officer.  In the communities which have had real success putting police officers near schools where kids carry weapons
column20: to get the weapons out of the schools
column21: are on the same blocks
column22: you've seen crime go down. In Houston there's been a 15- percent drop in the crime rate in the last year because of the work the mayor did there in increasing the police force. So I know it can work; I've seen it happen.

column1: I think you put your finger on a major problem. I talk about strengthening the American family and it's very hard to strengthen the family if people are scared to walk down to the corner store and
column2: you know
column3: send their kid down to get a loaf of bread. It's very hard. I have been fighting for very strong anti-crime legislation -- habeas corpus reform
column4: so you don't have these endless appeals
column6: hey
column7: this is for real. I've been fighting for changes in the exclusionary rule so if an honest cop stops somebody and makes a technical mistake
column8: the criminal doesn't go away.  I'll probably get into a fight in this room with some but I happen to think that we need stronger death penalties for those that kill police officers.  Virginia's in the lead in this
column9: as Governor Clinton properly said
column10: on this identification system for firearms. I am not for national registration of firearms. Some of the states that have the toughest anti-gun laws have the highest levels of crime. I am for the right
column11: as the governor says- -I'm a sportsman and I don't think you ought to eliminate all kinds of weapons. But I was not for the bill that he was talking about because it was not tough enough on the criminal.  I'm very pleased that the Fraternal Order of Police in Little Rock
column12: Arkansas endorsed me because I think they see I'm trying to strengthen the anti-crime legislation. We've got more money going out for local police than any previous administration.  So we've got to get it under control and there's one last point I'd make. Drugs. We have got to win our national strategy against drugs
column13: the fight against drugs. And we're making some progress
column14: doing a little better on interdiction. We're not doing as well amongst the people that get to be habitual drug-users.  The good news is
column15: and I think it's true in Richmond
column16: teenage use is down of cocaine
column17: substantially
column18: 60% in the last couple of years. So we're making progress but until we get that one done
column19: we're not going to solve the neighborhood crime problem.

column1: I didn't get to make a comment on this.
Oh
column2: you're going to let me. Excuse me.

column1: On any program
column2: and this includes crime
column3: you'll find we have all kinds of great plans lying around that never get enacted into law and implemented. I don't care what it is -- competitiveness
column4: health care
column6: you name it. Brady Bill
column7: I agree that it's a timid step in the right direction but it won't fix it. So why pass a law that won't fix it? Now
column8: what it really boils down to is can you live -- we become so preoccupied with the rights of the criminal that we've forgotten the rights of the innocent. And in our country we have evolved to a point where we've put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and they've put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately. That's where we are. We have got to become more concerned about people who play by the rules and get the balance we require. This is going to take first
column9: building a consensus at grassroots America. Right from the bottom up
column10: the American people have got to say they want it. And at that point
column11: we can pick from a variety of plans and develop new plans. And the way you get things done is bury yourselves in the room with one another
column12: put together the best program
column13: take it to the American people
column14: use the electronic town hall
column15: the kind of thing you're doing here tonight
column16: build a consensus and then do it and then go on to the next one. But don't just sit here slow dancing for 4 years doing nothing.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 6)	" I support the right to keep and bear arms. I live in a state where over half the adults have hunting or fishing licenses
column4: or both. But I believe we have to have some way of checking hand guns before they're sold
column6: the mental health history
column7: and the age of people who are buying them. Therefore I support the Brady bill which would impose a national waiting period unless and until a state did what only Virginia has done now
column8: which is to automate its records. Once you automate your records
column9: then you don't have to have a waiting period
column10: but at least you can check. I also think we should have frankly restrictions on assault weapons whose only purpose is to kill. We need to give the police a fighting chance in our urban areas where the gangs are building up.  The third thing I would say -- it doesn't bear directly on gun control
column11: but it's very important -- we need more police on the street. There is a crime bill which would put more police on the street
column12: which was killed for this session by a filibuster in the Senate
column13: mostly be Republican senators
column14: and I think it's a shame it didn't pass
column15: I think it should be made the law -- but it had the Brady bill in it
column16: the waiting period.  I also believe that we should offer college scholarships to people who will agree to work them off as police officers
column17: and I think
column18: as we reduce our military forces
column19: we should let people earn military retirement by coming out and working as police officers. Thirty years ago there were three police officers on the street for every crime; today there are three crimes for every police officer.  In the communities which have had real success putting police officers near schools where kids carry weapons
column20: to get the weapons out of the schools
column21: are on the same blocks
column22: you've seen crime go down. In Houston there's been a 15- percent drop in the crime rate in the last year because of the work the mayor did there in increasing the police force. So I know it can work; I've seen it happen.

column1: I think you put your finger on a major problem. I talk about strengthening the American family and it's very hard to strengthen the family if people are scared to walk down to the corner store and
column2: you know
column3: send their kid down to get a loaf of bread. It's very hard. I have been fighting for very strong anti-crime legislation -- habeas corpus reform
column4: so you don't have these endless appeals
column6: hey
column7: this is for real. I've been fighting for changes in the exclusionary rule so if an honest cop stops somebody and makes a technical mistake
column8: the criminal doesn't go away.  I'll probably get into a fight in this room with some but I happen to think that we need stronger death penalties for those that kill police officers.  Virginia's in the lead in this
column9: as Governor Clinton properly said
column10: on this identification system for firearms. I am not for national registration of firearms. Some of the states that have the toughest anti-gun laws have the highest levels of crime. I am for the right
column11: as the governor says- -I'm a sportsman and I don't think you ought to eliminate all kinds of weapons. But I was not for the bill that he was talking about because it was not tough enough on the criminal.  I'm very pleased that the Fraternal Order of Police in Little Rock
column12: Arkansas endorsed me because I think they see I'm trying to strengthen the anti-crime legislation. We've got more money going out for local police than any previous administration.  So we've got to get it under control and there's one last point I'd make. Drugs. We have got to win our national strategy against drugs
column13: the fight against drugs. And we're making some progress
column14: doing a little better on interdiction. We're not doing as well amongst the people that get to be habitual drug-users.  The good news is
column15: and I think it's true in Richmond
column16: teenage use is down of cocaine
column17: substantially
column18: 60% in the last couple of years. So we're making progress but until we get that one done
column19: we're not going to solve the neighborhood crime problem.

column1: On any program
column2: and this includes crime
column3: you'll find we have all kinds of great plans lying around that never get enacted into law and implemented. I don't care what it is -- competitiveness
column4: health care
column6: you name it. Brady Bill
column7: I agree that it's a timid step in the right direction but it won't fix it. So why pass a law that won't fix it? Now
column8: what it really boils down to is can you live -- we become so preoccupied with the rights of the criminal that we've forgotten the rights of the innocent. And in our country we have evolved to a point where we've put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and they've put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately. That's where we are. We have got to become more concerned about people who play by the rules and get the balance we require. This is going to take first
column9: building a consensus at grassroots America. Right from the bottom up
column10: the American people have got to say they want it. And at that point
column11: we can pick from a variety of plans and develop new plans. And the way you get things done is bury yourselves in the room with one another
column12: put together the best program
column13: take it to the American people
column14: use the electronic town hall
column15: the kind of thing you're doing here tonight
column16: build a consensus and then do it and then go on to the next one. But don't just sit here slow dancing for 4 years doing nothing.

column3: 6)	" I support the right to keep and bear arms. I live in a state where over half the adults have hunting or fishing licenses
column4: or both. But I believe we have to have some way of checking hand guns before they're sold
column6: the mental health history
column7: and the age of people who are buying them. Therefore I support the Brady bill which would impose a national waiting period unless and until a state did what only Virginia has done now
column8: which is to automate its records. Once you automate your records
column9: then you don't have to have a waiting period
column10: but at least you can check. I also think we should have frankly restrictions on assault weapons whose only purpose is to kill. We need to give the police a fighting chance in our urban areas where the gangs are building up.  The third thing I would say -- it doesn't bear directly on gun control
column11: but it's very important -- we need more police on the street. There is a crime bill which would put more police on the street
column12: which was killed for this session by a filibuster in the Senate
column13: mostly be Republican senators
column14: and I think it's a shame it didn't pass
column15: I think it should be made the law -- but it had the Brady bill in it
column16: the waiting period.  I also believe that we should offer college scholarships to people who will agree to work them off as police officers
column17: and I think
column18: as we reduce our military forces
column19: we should let people earn military retirement by coming out and working as police officers. Thirty years ago there were three police officers on the street for every crime; today there are three crimes for every police officer.  In the communities which have had real success putting police officers near schools where kids carry weapons
column20: to get the weapons out of the schools
column21: are on the same blocks
column22: you've seen crime go down. In Houston there's been a 15- percent drop in the crime rate in the last year because of the work the mayor did there in increasing the police force. So I know it can work; I've seen it happen.

column1: I think you put your finger on a major problem. I talk about strengthening the American family and it's very hard to strengthen the family if people are scared to walk down to the corner store and
column2: you know
column3: send their kid down to get a loaf of bread. It's very hard. I have been fighting for very strong anti-crime legislation -- habeas corpus reform
column4: so you don't have these endless appeals
column6: hey
column7: this is for real. I've been fighting for changes in the exclusionary rule so if an honest cop stops somebody and makes a technical mistake
column8: the criminal doesn't go away.  I'll probably get into a fight in this room with some but I happen to think that we need stronger death penalties for those that kill police officers.  Virginia's in the lead in this
column9: as Governor Clinton properly said
column10: on this identification system for firearms. I am not for national registration of firearms. Some of the states that have the toughest anti-gun laws have the highest levels of crime. I am for the right
column11: as the governor says- -I'm a sportsman and I don't think you ought to eliminate all kinds of weapons. But I was not for the bill that he was talking about because it was not tough enough on the criminal.  I'm very pleased that the Fraternal Order of Police in Little Rock
column12: Arkansas endorsed me because I think they see I'm trying to strengthen the anti-crime legislation. We've got more money going out for local police than any previous administration.  So we've got to get it under control and there's one last point I'd make. Drugs. We have got to win our national strategy against drugs
column13: the fight against drugs. And we're making some progress
column14: doing a little better on interdiction. We're not doing as well amongst the people that get to be habitual drug-users.  The good news is
column15: and I think it's true in Richmond
column16: teenage use is down of cocaine
column17: substantially
column18: 60% in the last couple of years. So we're making progress but until we get that one done
column19: we're not going to solve the neighborhood crime problem.

column1: On any program
column2: and this includes crime
column3: you'll find we have all kinds of great plans lying around that never get enacted into law and implemented. I don't care what it is -- competitiveness
column4: health care
column6: you name it. Brady Bill
column7: I agree that it's a timid step in the right direction but it won't fix it. So why pass a law that won't fix it? Now
column8: what it really boils down to is can you live -- we become so preoccupied with the rights of the criminal that we've forgotten the rights of the innocent. And in our country we have evolved to a point where we've put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and they've put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately. That's where we are. We have got to become more concerned about people who play by the rules and get the balance we require. This is going to take first
column9: building a consensus at grassroots America. Right from the bottom up
column10: the American people have got to say they want it. And at that point
column11: we can pick from a variety of plans and develop new plans. And the way you get things done is bury yourselves in the room with one another
column12: put together the best program
column13: take it to the American people
column14: use the electronic town hall
column15: the kind of thing you're doing here tonight
column16: build a consensus and then do it and then go on to the next one. But don't just sit here slow dancing for 4 years doing nothing.

column11: as the governor says- -I'm a sportsman and I don't think you ought to eliminate all kinds of weapons. But I was not for the bill that he was talking about because it was not tough enough on the criminal.  I'm very pleased that the Fraternal Order of Police in Little Rock
column12: Arkansas endorsed me because I think they see I'm trying to strengthen the anti-crime legislation. We've got more money going out for local police than any previous administration.  So we've got to get it under control and there's one last point I'd make. Drugs. We have got to win our national strategy against drugs
column13: the fight against drugs. And we're making some progress
column14: doing a little better on interdiction. We're not doing as well amongst the people that get to be habitual drug-users.  The good news is
column15: and I think it's true in Richmond
column16: teenage use is down of cocaine
column17: substantially
column18: 60% in the last couple of years. So we're making progress but until we get that one done
column19: we're not going to solve the neighborhood crime problem.

column1: I didn't get to make a comment on this.
Oh
column2: you're going to let me. Excuse me.

column1: On any program
column2: and this includes crime
column3: you'll find we have all kinds of great plans lying around that never get enacted into law and implemented. I don't care what it is -- competitiveness
column4: health care
column6: you name it. Brady Bill
column7: I agree that it's a timid step in the right direction but it won't fix it. So why pass a law that won't fix it? Now
column8: what it really boils down to is can you live -- we become so preoccupied with the rights of the criminal that we've forgotten the rights of the innocent. And in our country we have evolved to a point where we've put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and they've put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately. That's where we are. We have got to become more concerned about people who play by the rules and get the balance we require. This is going to take first
column9: building a consensus at grassroots America. Right from the bottom up
column10: the American people have got to say they want it. And at that point
column11: we can pick from a variety of plans and develop new plans. And the way you get things done is bury yourselves in the room with one another
column12: put together the best program
column13: take it to the American people
column14: use the electronic town hall
column15: the kind of thing you're doing here tonight
column16: build a consensus and then do it and then go on to the next one. But don't just sit here slow dancing for 4 years doing nothing.
