column3: 6)	" I support the right to keep and bear arms. I live in a state where over half the adults have hunting or fishing licenses
column4: or both. But I believe we have to have some way of checking hand guns before they're sold
column6: the mental health history
column7: and the age of people who are buying them. Therefore I support the Brady bill which would impose a national waiting period unless and until a state did what only Virginia has done now
column8: which is to automate its records. Once you automate your records
column9: then you don't have to have a waiting period
column10: but at least you can check. I also think we should have frankly restrictions on assault weapons whose only purpose is to kill. We need to give the police a fighting chance in our urban areas where the gangs are building up.  The third thing I would say -- it doesn't bear directly on gun control
column11: but it's very important -- we need more police on the street. There is a crime bill which would put more police on the street
column12: which was killed for this session by a filibuster in the Senate
column13: mostly be Republican senators
column14: and I think it's a shame it didn't pass
column15: I think it should be made the law -- but it had the Brady bill in it
column16: the waiting period.  I also believe that we should offer college scholarships to people who will agree to work them off as police officers
column17: and I think
column18: as we reduce our military forces
column19: we should let people earn military retirement by coming out and working as police officers. Thirty years ago there were three police officers on the street for every crime; today there are three crimes for every police officer.  In the communities which have had real success putting police officers near schools where kids carry weapons
column20: to get the weapons out of the schools
column21: are on the same blocks
column22: you've seen crime go down. In Houston there's been a 15- percent drop in the crime rate in the last year because of the work the mayor did there in increasing the police force. So I know it can work; I've seen it happen.

column1: I think you put your finger on a major problem. I talk about strengthening the American family and it's very hard to strengthen the family if people are scared to walk down to the corner store and
column2: you know
column3: send their kid down to get a loaf of bread. It's very hard. I have been fighting for very strong anti-crime legislation -- habeas corpus reform
column4: so you don't have these endless appeals
column6: hey
column7: this is for real. I've been fighting for changes in the exclusionary rule so if an honest cop stops somebody and makes a technical mistake
column8: the criminal doesn't go away.  I'll probably get into a fight in this room with some but I happen to think that we need stronger death penalties for those that kill police officers.  Virginia's in the lead in this
column9: as Governor Clinton properly said
column10: on this identification system for firearms. I am not for national registration of firearms. Some of the states that have the toughest anti-gun laws have the highest levels of crime. I am for the right
column11: as the governor says- -I'm a sportsman and I don't think you ought to eliminate all kinds of weapons. But I was not for the bill that he was talking about because it was not tough enough on the criminal.  I'm very pleased that the Fraternal Order of Police in Little Rock
column12: Arkansas endorsed me because I think they see I'm trying to strengthen the anti-crime legislation. We've got more money going out for local police than any previous administration.  So we've got to get it under control and there's one last point I'd make. Drugs. We have got to win our national strategy against drugs
column13: the fight against drugs. And we're making some progress
column14: doing a little better on interdiction. We're not doing as well amongst the people that get to be habitual drug-users.  The good news is
column15: and I think it's true in Richmond
column16: teenage use is down of cocaine
column17: substantially
column18: 60% in the last couple of years. So we're making progress but until we get that one done
column19: we're not going to solve the neighborhood crime problem.

column1: I didn't get to make a comment on this.
Oh
column2: you're going to let me. Excuse me.

column1: On any program
column2: and this includes crime
column3: you'll find we have all kinds of great plans lying around that never get enacted into law and implemented. I don't care what it is -- competitiveness
column4: health care
column6: you name it. Brady Bill
column7: I agree that it's a timid step in the right direction but it won't fix it. So why pass a law that won't fix it? Now
column8: what it really boils down to is can you live -- we become so preoccupied with the rights of the criminal that we've forgotten the rights of the innocent. And in our country we have evolved to a point where we've put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and they've put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately. That's where we are. We have got to become more concerned about people who play by the rules and get the balance we require. This is going to take first
column9: building a consensus at grassroots America. Right from the bottom up
column10: the American people have got to say they want it. And at that point
column11: we can pick from a variety of plans and develop new plans. And the way you get things done is bury yourselves in the room with one another
column12: put together the best program
column13: take it to the American people
column14: use the electronic town hall
column15: the kind of thing you're doing here tonight
column16: build a consensus and then do it and then go on to the next one. But don't just sit here slow dancing for 4 years doing nothing.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 6)	" I support the right to keep and bear arms. I live in a state where over half the adults have hunting or fishing licenses
column4: or both. But I believe we have to have some way of checking hand guns before they're sold
column6: the mental health history
column7: and the age of people who are buying them. Therefore I support the Brady bill which would impose a national waiting period unless and until a state did what only Virginia has done now
column8: which is to automate its records. Once you automate your records
column9: then you don't have to have a waiting period
column10: but at least you can check. I also think we should have frankly restrictions on assault weapons whose only purpose is to kill. We need to give the police a fighting chance in our urban areas where the gangs are building up.  The third thing I would say -- it doesn't bear directly on gun control
column11: but it's very important -- we need more police on the street. There is a crime bill which would put more police on the street
column12: which was killed for this session by a filibuster in the Senate
column13: mostly be Republican senators
column14: and I think it's a shame it didn't pass
column15: I think it should be made the law -- but it had the Brady bill in it
column16: the waiting period.  I also believe that we should offer college scholarships to people who will agree to work them off as police officers
column17: and I think
column18: as we reduce our military forces
column19: we should let people earn military retirement by coming out and working as police officers. Thirty years ago there were three police officers on the street for every crime; today there are three crimes for every police officer.  In the communities which have had real success putting police officers near schools where kids carry weapons
column20: to get the weapons out of the schools
column21: are on the same blocks
column22: you've seen crime go down. In Houston there's been a 15- percent drop in the crime rate in the last year because of the work the mayor did there in increasing the police force. So I know it can work; I've seen it happen.

column1: I think you put your finger on a major problem. I talk about strengthening the American family and it's very hard to strengthen the family if people are scared to walk down to the corner store and
column2: you know
column3: send their kid down to get a loaf of bread. It's very hard. I have been fighting for very strong anti-crime legislation -- habeas corpus reform
column4: so you don't have these endless appeals
column6: hey
column7: this is for real. I've been fighting for changes in the exclusionary rule so if an honest cop stops somebody and makes a technical mistake
column8: the criminal doesn't go away.  I'll probably get into a fight in this room with some but I happen to think that we need stronger death penalties for those that kill police officers.  Virginia's in the lead in this
column9: as Governor Clinton properly said
column10: on this identification system for firearms. I am not for national registration of firearms. Some of the states that have the toughest anti-gun laws have the highest levels of crime. I am for the right
column11: as the governor says- -I'm a sportsman and I don't think you ought to eliminate all kinds of weapons. But I was not for the bill that he was talking about because it was not tough enough on the criminal.  I'm very pleased that the Fraternal Order of Police in Little Rock
column12: Arkansas endorsed me because I think they see I'm trying to strengthen the anti-crime legislation. We've got more money going out for local police than any previous administration.  So we've got to get it under control and there's one last point I'd make. Drugs. We have got to win our national strategy against drugs
column13: the fight against drugs. And we're making some progress
column14: doing a little better on interdiction. We're not doing as well amongst the people that get to be habitual drug-users.  The good news is
column15: and I think it's true in Richmond
column16: teenage use is down of cocaine
column17: substantially
column18: 60% in the last couple of years. So we're making progress but until we get that one done
column19: we're not going to solve the neighborhood crime problem.

column1: I didn't get to make a comment on this.
Oh
column2: you're going to let me. Excuse me.

column1: On any program
column2: and this includes crime
column3: you'll find we have all kinds of great plans lying around that never get enacted into law and implemented. I don't care what it is -- competitiveness
column4: health care
column6: you name it. Brady Bill
column7: I agree that it's a timid step in the right direction but it won't fix it. So why pass a law that won't fix it? Now
column8: what it really boils down to is can you live -- we become so preoccupied with the rights of the criminal that we've forgotten the rights of the innocent. And in our country we have evolved to a point where we've put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and they've put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately. That's where we are. We have got to become more concerned about people who play by the rules and get the balance we require. This is going to take first
column9: building a consensus at grassroots America. Right from the bottom up
column10: the American people have got to say they want it. And at that point
column11: we can pick from a variety of plans and develop new plans. And the way you get things done is bury yourselves in the room with one another
column12: put together the best program
column13: take it to the American people
column14: use the electronic town hall
column15: the kind of thing you're doing here tonight
column16: build a consensus and then do it and then go on to the next one. But don't just sit here slow dancing for 4 years doing nothing.

waiting period unless and until a state did what only Virginia has done now, which is to automate its records', 'Once you automate your records, then you dont have to have a waiting period, but at least you can check', 'I also think we should have frankly restrictions on assault weapons whose only purpose is to kill', 'We need to give the police a fighting chance in our urban areas where the gangs are building up', 'The third thing I would say  it doesnt bear directly on gun control, but its very important  we need more police on the street', 'There is a crime bill which would put more police on the street, which was killed for this session by a filibuster in the Senate, mostly be Republican senators, and I think its a shame it didnt pass, I think it should be made the law  but it had the Brady bill in it, the waiting period', 'I also believe that we should offer college scholarships to people who will agree to work them off as police officers, and I think, as we reduce our military forces, we should let people earn military retirement by coming out and working as police officers', 'Thirty years ago there were three police officers on the street for every crime; today there are three crimes for every police officer', 'In the communities which have had real success putting police officers near schools where kids carry weapons, to get the weapons out of the schools, are on the same blocks, youve seen crime go down', 'In Houston theres been a 15 percent drop in the crime rate in the last year because of the work the mayor did there in increasing the police force', 'So I know it can work; Ive seen it happen', 'I think you put your finger on a major problem', 'I talk about strengthening the American family and its very hard to strengthen the family if people are scared to walk down to the corner store and, you know, send their kid down to get a loaf of bread', 'Its very hard', 'I have been fighting for very strong anticrime legislation  habeas corpus reform, so you dont have these endless appeals, so when somebody gets sentenced, hey, this is for real', 'Ive been fighting for changes in the exclusionary rule so if an honest cop stops somebody and makes a technical mistake, the criminal doesnt go away', 'Ill probably get into a fight in this room with some but I happen to think that we need stronger death penalties for those that kill police officers', 'Virginias in the lead in this, as Governor Clinton properly said, on this identification system for firearms', 'I am not for national registration of firearms', 'Some of the states that have the toughest antigun laws have the highest levels of crime', 'I am for the right, as the governor says Im a sportsman and I dont think you ought to eliminate all kinds of weapons', 'But I was not for the bill that he was talking about because it was not tough enough on the criminal', 'Im very pleased that the Fraternal Order of Police in Little Rock, Arkansas endorsed me because I think they see Im trying to strengthen the anticrime legislation', 'Weve got more money going out for local police than any previous administration', 'So weve got to get it under control and theres one last point Id crime, you name it', 'Brady Bill, I agree that its a timid step in the right direction but it wont fix it', 'So why pass a law that wont fix it?', 'Now, what it really boils down to is can you live  we become so preoccupied with the rights of the criminal that weve forgotten the rights of the innocent', 'And in our country we have evolved to a point where weve put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and theyve put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately', 'Thats where we are', 'We have got to become more concerned about people who play by the rules and get the balance we require', 'This is going to take first, building a consensus at grassroots America', yourselves in the room with one another, put together the best program, take it to the American people, use the electronic town hall, the kind of thing youre doing here tonight, build a consensus and then do it and then go on to the next one', 'But dont just sit here slow dancing for 4 years doing nothing']	['I support the right to keep and bear arms.'

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 7)	" Any order? I'll be glad to respond.

column1: I strongly support term limits for members of the US Congress. I believe it would return the government closer to the people
column2: the way that Ross Perot is talking about. The president's terms are limited to 2
column3: a total of 8 years. What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12? Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized. For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives
column4: and the result
column5: a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together. We've got to do something about it. And I think you get a certain arrogance
column6: bureaucratic arrogance
column7: if people stay there too long. And so I favor
column8: strongly favor
column9: term limits.  And how to get them passed? Send us some people that will pass the idea. And I think you will. I think the American people want it now. Every place I go I talk about it
column10: and I think they want it done. Actually
column11: you'd have to have some amendments to the Constitution because of the way the Constitution reads.

column1: I know they're popular
column2: but I'm against them. I'll tell you why. I believe
column3: number one
column4: it would pose a real problem for a lot of smaller states in the Congress who have enough trouble now making sure their interests are heard. Number 2
column5: I think it would increase the influence of unelected staff members in the Congress who have too much influence already. I want to cut the size of the congressional staffs
column6: but I think you're going to have too much influence there with people who were never elected
column7: who have lots of expertise. Number 3
column8: if the people really have a mind to change
column9: they can. You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress.  Now
column10: let me tell you what I favor instead. I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress
column11: strict limits on political action committees
column12: requirements that people running for Congress appear in open public debates like we're doing now. If you did that you could take away the incumbents' advantage because challengers like me would have a chance to run against incumbents like him for House races and Senate races
column13: and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight.  So that's how I feel about it
column14: and I think if we had the right kind of campaign reform
column15: we'd get the changes you want.

column1: Yes. Let me do first on a personal level. If the American people send me up to do this job
column2: I intend to be there one term. I do not intend to spend one minute of one day thinking about re-election. And as a matter of principle -- and my situation is unique
column3: and I understand it -- I would take absolutely no compensation; I go as their servant. Now
column4: I have set as strong an example as I can
column5: then at that point when we sit down over at Capitol Hill -- tomorrow night I'm going to be talking about government reform -- it's a long subject
column6: you wouldn't let me finish tonight. If you want to hear it
column7: you get it tomorrow night -- you'll hear it tomorrow night.  But we have got to reform government. If you put term limits in and don't reform government
column8: you won't get the benefits you thought. It takes both. So we need to do the reforms and the term limits. And after we reform it
column9: it won't be a lifetime career opportunity; good people will go serve and then go back to their homes and not become foreign lobbyists and cash in at 30
column10: 000 bucks a month and then take time off to run some president's campaign.  They're all nice people
column11: they're just in a bad system. I don't think there are any villains
column12: but
column13: boy
column14: is the system rotten.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 7)	" Any order? I'll be glad to respond.

column1: I strongly support term limits for members of the US Congress. I believe it would return the government closer to the people
column2: the way that Ross Perot is talking about. The president's terms are limited to 2
column3: a total of 8 years. What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12? Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized. For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives
column4: and the result
column5: a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together. We've got to do something about it. And I think you get a certain arrogance
column6: bureaucratic arrogance
column7: if people stay there too long. And so I favor
column8: strongly favor
column9: term limits.  And how to get them passed? Send us some people that will pass the idea. And I think you will. I think the American people want it now. Every place I go I talk about it
column10: and I think they want it done. Actually
column11: you'd have to have some amendments to the Constitution because of the way the Constitution reads.

column1: I know they're popular
column2: but I'm against them. I'll tell you why. I believe
column3: number one
column4: it would pose a real problem for a lot of smaller states in the Congress who have enough trouble now making sure their interests are heard. Number 2
column5: I think it would increase the influence of unelected staff members in the Congress who have too much influence already. I want to cut the size of the congressional staffs
column6: but I think you're going to have too much influence there with people who were never elected
column7: who have lots of expertise. Number 3
column8: if the people really have a mind to change
column9: they can. You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress.  Now
column10: let me tell you what I favor instead. I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress
column11: strict limits on political action committees
column12: requirements that people running for Congress appear in open public debates like we're doing now. If you did that you could take away the incumbents' advantage because challengers like me would have a chance to run against incumbents like him for House races and Senate races
column13: and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight.  So that's how I feel about it
column14: and I think if we had the right kind of campaign reform
column15: we'd get the changes you want.

column1: Yes. Let me do first on a personal level. If the American people send me up to do this job
column2: I intend to be there one term. I do not intend to spend one minute of one day thinking about re-election. And as a matter of principle -- and my situation is unique
column3: and I understand it -- I would take absolutely no compensation; I go as their servant. Now
column4: I have set as strong an example as I can
column5: then at that point when we sit down over at Capitol Hill -- tomorrow night I'm going to be talking about government reform -- it's a long subject
column6: you wouldn't let me finish tonight. If you want to hear it
column7: you get it tomorrow night -- you'll hear it tomorrow night.  But we have got to reform government. If you put term limits in and don't reform government
column8: you won't get the benefits you thought. It takes both. So we need to do the reforms and the term limits. And after we reform it
column9: it won't be a lifetime career opportunity; good people will go serve and then go back to their homes and not become foreign lobbyists and cash in at 30
column10: 000 bucks a month and then take time off to run some president's campaign.  They're all nice people
column11: they're just in a bad system. I don't think there are any villains
column12: but

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 7)	" Any order? I'll be glad to respond.

column1: I strongly support term limits for members of the US Congress. I believe it would return the government closer to the people
column2: the way that Ross Perot is talking about. The president's terms are limited to 2
column3: a total of 8 years. What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12? Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized. For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives
column4: and the result
column5: a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together. We've got to do something about it. And I think you get a certain arrogance
column6: bureaucratic arrogance
column7: if people stay there too long. And so I favor
column8: strongly favor
column9: term limits.  And how to get them passed? Send us some people that will pass the idea. And I think you will. I think the American people want it now. Every place I go I talk about it
column10: and I think they want it done. Actually
column11: you'd have to have some amendments to the Constitution because of the way the Constitution reads.

column1: I know they're popular
column2: but I'm against them. I'll tell you why. I believe
column3: number one
column4: it would pose a real problem for a lot of smaller states in the Congress who have enough trouble now making sure their interests are heard. Number 2
column5: I think it would increase the influence of unelected staff members in the Congress who have too much influence already. I want to cut the size of the congressional staffs
column6: but I think you're going to have too much influence there with people who were never elected
column7: who have lots of expertise. Number 3
column8: if the people really have a mind to change
column9: they can. You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress.  Now
column10: let me tell you what I favor instead. I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress
column11: strict limits on political action committees
column12: requirements that people running for Congress appear in open public debates like we're doing now. If you did that you could take away the incumbents' advantage because challengers like me would have a chance to run against incumbents like him for House races and Senate races
column13: and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight.  So that's how I feel about it
column14: and I think if we had the right kind of campaign reform
column15: we'd get the changes you want.

column1: Yes. Let me do first on a personal level. If the American people send me up to do this job
column2: I intend to be there one term. I do not intend to spend one minute of one day thinking about re-election. And as a matter of principle -- and my situation is unique
column3: and I understand it -- I would take absolutely no compensation; I go as their servant. Now
column4: I have set as strong an example as I can
column5: then at that point when we sit down over at Capitol Hill -- tomorrow night I'm going to be talking about government reform -- it's a long subject
column6: you wouldn't let me finish tonight. If you want to hear it
column7: you get it tomorrow night -- you'll hear it tomorrow night.  But we have got to reform government. If you put term limits in and don't reform government
column8: you won't get the benefits you thought. It takes both. So we need to do the reforms and the term limits. And after we reform it
column9: it won't be a lifetime career opportunity; good people will go serve and then go back to their homes and not become foreign lobbyists and cash in at 30
column10: 000 bucks a month and then take time off to run some president's campaign.  They're all nice people
column11: they're just in a bad system. I don't think there are any villains
column12: but
column13: boy
column14: is the system rotten.

column1: I strongly support term limits for members of the US Congress. I believe it would return the government closer to the people
column2: the way that Ross Perot is talking about. The president's terms are limited to 2
column3: a total of 8 years. What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12? Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized. For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives
column4: and the result
column5: a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together. We've got to do something about it. And I think you get a certain arrogance
column6: bureaucratic arrogance
column7: if people stay there too long. And so I favor
column8: strongly favor
column9: term limits.  And how to get them passed? Send us some people that will pass the idea. And I think you will. I think the American people want it now. Every place I go I talk about it
column10: and I think they want it done. Actually
column11: you'd have to have some amendments to the Constitution because of the way the Constitution reads.

column1: I know they're popular
column2: but I'm against them. I'll tell you why. I believe
column3: number one
column4: it would pose a real problem for a lot of smaller states in the Congress who have enough trouble now making sure their interests are heard. Number 2
column5: I think it would increase the influence of unelected staff members in the Congress who have too much influence already. I want to cut the size of the congressional staffs
column6: but I think you're going to have too much influence there with people who were never elected
column7: who have lots of expertise. Number 3
column8: if the people really have a mind to change
column9: they can. You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress.  Now
column10: let me tell you what I favor instead. I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress
column11: strict limits on political action committees
column12: requirements that people running for Congress appear in open public debates like we're doing now. If you did that you could take away the incumbents' advantage because challengers like me would have a chance to run against incumbents like him for House races and Senate races
column13: and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight.  So that's how I feel about it
column14: and I think if we had the right kind of campaign reform
column15: we'd get the changes you want.

column3: 7)	" Any order? I'll be glad to respond.

column1: I strongly support term limits for members of the US Congress. I believe it would return the government closer to the people
column2: the way that Ross Perot is talking about. The president's terms are limited to 2
column3: a total of 8 years. What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12? Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized. For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives
column4: and the result
column5: a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together. We've got to do something about it. And I think you get a certain arrogance
column6: bureaucratic arrogance
column7: if people stay there too long. And so I favor
column8: strongly favor
column9: term limits.  And how to get them passed? Send us some people that will pass the idea. And I think you will. I think the American people want it now. Every place I go I talk about it
column10: and I think they want it done. Actually
column11: you'd have to have some amendments to the Constitution because of the way the Constitution reads.

column1: I know they're popular
column2: but I'm against them. I'll tell you why. I believe
column3: number one
column4: it would pose a real problem for a lot of smaller states in the Congress who have enough trouble now making sure their interests are heard. Number 2
column5: I think it would increase the influence of unelected staff members in the Congress who have too much influence already. I want to cut the size of the congressional staffs
column6: but I think you're going to have too much influence there with people who were never elected
column7: who have lots of expertise. Number 3
column8: if the people really have a mind to change
column9: they can. You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress.  Now
column10: let me tell you what I favor instead. I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress
column11: strict limits on political action committees
column12: requirements that people running for Congress appear in open public debates like we're doing now. If you did that you could take away the incumbents' advantage because challengers like me would have a chance to run against incumbents like him for House races and Senate races
column13: and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight.  So that's how I feel about it
column14: and I think if we had the right kind of campaign reform
column15: we'd get the changes you want.

column1: Yes. Let me do first on a personal level. If the American people send me up to do this job
column2: I intend to be there one term. I do not intend to spend one minute of one day thinking about re-election. And as a matter of principle -- and my situation is unique
column3: and I understand it -- I would take absolutely no compensation; I go as their servant. Now
column4: I have set as strong an example as I can
column5: then at that point when we sit down over at Capitol Hill -- tomorrow night I'm going to be talking about government reform -- it's a long subject
column6: you wouldn't let me finish tonight. If you want to hear it
column7: you get it tomorrow night -- you'll hear it tomorrow night.  But we have got to reform government. If you put term limits in and don't reform government
column8: you won't get the benefits you thought. It takes both. So we need to do the reforms and the term limits. And after we reform it
column9: it won't be a lifetime career opportunity; good people will go serve and then go back to their homes and not become foreign lobbyists and cash in at 30
column10: 000 bucks a month and then take time off to run some president's campaign.  They're all nice people
column11: they're just in a bad system. I don't think there are any villains
column12: but
column13: boy
column14: is the system rotten.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 7)	" Any order? I'll be glad to respond.

column1: I strongly support term limits for members of the US Congress. I believe it would return the government closer to the people
column2: the way that Ross Perot is talking about. The president's terms are limited to 2
column3: a total of 8 years. What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12? Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized. For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives
column4: and the result
column5: a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together. We've got to do something about it. And I think you get a certain arrogance
column6: bureaucratic arrogance
column7: if people stay there too long. And so I favor
column8: strongly favor
column9: term limits.  And how to get them passed? Send us some people that will pass the idea. And I think you will. I think the American people want it now. Every place I go I talk about it
column10: and I think they want it done. Actually
column11: you'd have to have some amendments to the Constitution because of the way the Constitution reads.

column1: I know they're popular
column2: but I'm against them. I'll tell you why. I believe
column3: number one
column4: it would pose a real problem for a lot of smaller states in the Congress who have enough trouble now making sure their interests are heard. Number 2
column5: I think it would increase the influence of unelected staff members in the Congress who have too much influence already. I want to cut the size of the congressional staffs
column6: but I think you're going to have too much influence there with people who were never elected
column7: who have lots of expertise. Number 3
column8: if the people really have a mind to change
column9: they can. You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress.  Now
column10: let me tell you what I favor instead. I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress
column11: strict limits on political action committees
column12: requirements that people running for Congress appear in open public debates like we're doing now. If you did that you could take away the incumbents' advantage because challengers like me would have a chance to run against incumbents like him for House races and Senate races
column13: and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight.  So that's how I feel about it
column14: and I think if we had the right kind of campaign reform
column15: we'd get the changes you want.

column1: Yes. Let me do first on a personal level. If the American people send me up to do this job
column2: I intend to be there one term. I do not intend to spend one minute of one day thinking about re-election. And as a matter of principle -- and my situation is unique
column3: and I understand it -- I would take absolutely no compensation; I go as their servant. Now
column4: I have set as strong an example as I can
column5: then at that point when we sit down over at Capitol Hill -- tomorrow night I'm going to be talking about government reform -- it's a long subject
column6: you wouldn't let me finish tonight. If you want to hear it
column7: you get it tomorrow night -- you'll hear it tomorrow night.  But we have got to reform government. If you put term limits in and don't reform government
column8: you won't get the benefits you thought. It takes both. So we need to do the reforms and the term limits. And after we reform it
column9: it won't be a lifetime career opportunity; good people will go serve and then go back to their homes and not become foreign lobbyists and cash in at 30
column10: 000 bucks a month and then take time off to run some president's campaign.  They're all nice people
column11: they're just in a bad system. I don't think there are any villains
column12: but
column13: boy
column14: is the system rotten.

column1: I strongly support term limits for members of the US Congress. I believe it would return the government closer to the people
column2: the way that Ross Perot is talking about. The president's terms are limited to 2
column3: a total of 8 years. What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12? Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized. For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives
column4: and the result
column5: a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together. We've got to do something about it. And I think you get a certain arrogance
column6: bureaucratic arrogance
column7: if people stay there too long. And so I favor
column8: strongly favor
column9: term limits.  And how to get them passed? Send us some people that will pass the idea. And I think you will. I think the American people want it now. Every place I go I talk about it
column10: and I think they want it done. Actually
column11: you'd have to have some amendments to the Constitution because of the way the Constitution reads.

column6: but I think you're going to have too much influence there with people who were never elected
column7: who have lots of expertise. Number 3
column8: if the people really have a mind to change
column9: they can. You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress.  Now
column10: let me tell you what I favor instead. I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress

column13: and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight.  So that's how I feel about it
column14: and I think if we had the right kind of campaign reform
column15: we'd get the changes you want.

column5: a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together. We've got to do something about it. And I think you get a certain arrogance
column6: bureaucratic arrogance
column7: if people stay there too long. And so I favor
column8: strongly favor
column9: term limits.  And how to get them passed? Send us some people that will pass the idea. And I think you will. I think the American people want it now. Every place I go I talk about it
column10: and I think they want it done. Actually
column11: you'd have to have some amendments to the Constitution because of the way the Constitution reads.

column1: I know they're popular
column2: but I'm against them. I'll tell you why. I believe
column3: number one
column4: it would pose a real problem for a lot of smaller states in the Congress who have enough trouble now making sure their interests are heard. Number 2
column5: I think it would increase the influence of unelected staff members in the Congress who have too much influence already. I want to cut the size of the congressional staffs
column6: but I think you're going to have too much influence there with people who were never elected
column7: who have lots of expertise. Number 3
column8: if the people really have a mind to change
column9: they can. You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress.  Now
column10: let me tell you what I favor instead. I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress
column11: strict limits on political action committees
column12: requirements that people running for Congress appear in open public debates like we're doing now. If you did that you could take away the incumbents' advantage because challengers like me would have a chance to run against incumbents like him for House races and Senate races
column13: and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight.  So that's how I feel about it
column14: and I think if we had the right kind of campaign reform
column15: we'd get the changes you want.

column1: Yes. Let me do first on a personal level. If the American people send me up to do this job
column2: I intend to be there one term. I do not intend to spend one minute of one day thinking about re-election. And as a matter of principle -- and my situation is unique
column3: and I understand it -- I would take absolutely no compensation; I go as their servant. Now
column4: I have set as strong an example as I can
column5: then at that point when we sit down over at Capitol Hill -- tomorrow night I'm going to be talking about government reform -- it's a long subject
column6: you wouldn't let me finish tonight. If you want to hear it
column7: you get it tomorrow night -- you'll hear it tomorrow night.  But we have got to reform government. If you put term limits in and don't reform government
column8: you won't get the benefits you thought. It takes both. So we need to do the reforms and the term limits. And after we reform it
column9: it won't be a lifetime career opportunity; good people will go serve and then go back to their homes and not become foreign lobbyists and cash in at 30
column10: 000 bucks a month and then take time off to run some president's campaign.  They're all nice people
column11: they're just in a bad system. I don't think there are any villains
column12: but
column13: boy
column14: is the system rotten.

column3: 7)	" Any order? I'll be glad to respond.

column1: I strongly support term limits for members of the US Congress. I believe it would return the government closer to the people
column2: the way that Ross Perot is talking about. The president's terms are limited to 2
column3: a total of 8 years. What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12? Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized. For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives
column4: and the result
column5: a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together. We've got to do something about it. And I think you get a certain arrogance
column6: bureaucratic arrogance
column7: if people stay there too long. And so I favor
column8: strongly favor
column9: term limits.  And how to get them passed? Send us some people that will pass the idea. And I think you will. I think the American people want it now. Every place I go I talk about it
column10: and I think they want it done. Actually
column11: you'd have to have some amendments to the Constitution because of the way the Constitution reads.

column1: I know they're popular
column2: but I'm against them. I'll tell you why. I believe
column3: number one
column4: it would pose a real problem for a lot of smaller states in the Congress who have enough trouble now making sure their interests are heard. Number 2
column5: I think it would increase the influence of unelected staff members in the Congress who have too much influence already. I want to cut the size of the congressional staffs
column6: but I think you're going to have too much influence there with people who were never elected
column7: who have lots of expertise. Number 3
column8: if the people really have a mind to change
column9: they can. You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress.  Now
column10: let me tell you what I favor instead. I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress
column11: strict limits on political action committees
column12: requirements that people running for Congress appear in open public debates like we're doing now. If you did that you could take away the incumbents' advantage because challengers like me would have a chance to run against incumbents like him for House races and Senate races
column13: and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight.  So that's how I feel about it
column14: and I think if we had the right kind of campaign reform
column15: we'd get the changes you want.

column1: Yes. Let me do first on a personal level. If the American people send me up to do this job
column2: I intend to be there one term. I do not intend to spend one minute of one day thinking about re-election. And as a matter of principle -- and my situation is unique
column3: and I understand it -- I would take absolutely no compensation; I go as their servant. Now
column4: I have set as strong an example as I can
column5: then at that point when we sit down over at Capitol Hill -- tomorrow night I'm going to be talking about government reform -- it's a long subject
column6: you wouldn't let me finish tonight. If you want to hear it
column7: you get it tomorrow night -- you'll hear it tomorrow night.  But we have got to reform government. If you put term limits in and don't reform government
column8: you won't get the benefits you thought. It takes both. So we need to do the reforms and the term limits. And after we reform it
column9: it won't be a lifetime career opportunity; good people will go serve and then go back to their homes and not become foreign lobbyists and cash in at 30
column10: 000 bucks a month and then take time off to run some president's campaign.  They're all nice people
column11: they're just in a bad system. I don't think there are any villains
column12: but
column13: boy
column14: is the system rotten.

column3: 7)	" Any order? I'll be glad to respond.

column1: I strongly support term limits for members of the US Congress. I believe it would return the government closer to the people
column2: the way that Ross Perot is talking about. The president's terms are limited to 2
column3: a total of 8 years. What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12? Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized. For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives
column4: and the result
column5: a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together. We've got to do something about it. And I think you get a certain arrogance
column6: bureaucratic arrogance
column7: if people stay there too long. And so I favor
column8: strongly favor
column9: term limits.  And how to get them passed? Send us some people that will pass the idea. And I think you will. I think the American people want it now. Every place I go I talk about it
column10: and I think they want it done. Actually
column11: you'd have to have some amendments to the Constitution because of the way the Constitution reads.

column1: I know they're popular
column2: but I'm against them. I'll tell you why. I believe
column3: number one
column4: it would pose a real problem for a lot of smaller states in the Congress who have enough trouble now making sure their interests are heard. Number 2
column5: I think it would increase the influence of unelected staff members in the Congress who have too much influence already. I want to cut the size of the congressional staffs
column6: but I think you're going to have too much influence there with people who were never elected
column7: who have lots of expertise. Number 3
column8: if the people really have a mind to change
column9: they can. You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress.  Now
column10: let me tell you what I favor instead. I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress
column11: strict limits on political action committees
column12: requirements that people running for Congress appear in open public debates like we're doing now. If you did that you could take away the incumbents' advantage because challengers like me would have a chance to run against incumbents like him for House races and Senate races
column13: and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight.  So that's how I feel about it
column14: and I think if we had the right kind of campaign reform
column15: we'd get the changes you want.

column1: Yes. Let me do first on a personal level. If the American people send me up to do this job
column2: I intend to be there one term. I do not intend to spend one minute of one day thinking about re-election. And as a matter of principle -- and my situation is unique
column3: and I understand it -- I would take absolutely no compensation; I go as their servant. Now
column4: I have set as strong an example as I can
column5: then at that point when we sit down over at Capitol Hill -- tomorrow night I'm going to be talking about government reform -- it's a long subject
column6: you wouldn't let me finish tonight. If you want to hear it
column7: you get it tomorrow night -- you'll hear it tomorrow night.  But we have got to reform government. If you put term limits in and don't reform government
column8: you won't get the benefits you thought. It takes both. So we need to do the reforms and the term limits. And after we reform it
column9: it won't be a lifetime career opportunity; good people will go serve and then go back to their homes and not become foreign lobbyists and cash in at 30
column10: 000 bucks a month and then take time off to run some president's campaign.  They're all nice people
column11: they're just in a bad system. I don't think there are any villains
column12: but
column13: boy
column14: is the system rotten.

column1: I strongly support term limits for members of the US Congress. I believe it would return the government closer to the people
column2: the way that Ross Perot is talking about. The president's terms are limited to 2
column3: a total of 8 years. What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12? Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized. For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives
column4: and the result
column5: a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together. We've got to do something about it. And I think you get a certain arrogance
column6: bureaucratic arrogance
column7: if people stay there too long. And so I favor
column8: strongly favor
column9: term limits.  And how to get them passed? Send us some people that will pass the idea. And I think you will. I think the American people want it now. Every place I go I talk about it
column10: and I think they want it done. Actually
column11: you'd have to have some amendments to the Constitution because of the way the Constitution reads.

column1: I know they're popular
column2: but I'm against them. I'll tell you why. I believe
column3: number one
column4: it would pose a real problem for a lot of smaller states in the Congress who have enough trouble now making sure their interests are heard. Number 2
column5: I think it would increase the influence of unelected staff members in the Congress who have too much influence already. I want to cut the size of the congressional staffs
column6: but I think you're going to have too much influence there with people who were never elected
column7: who have lots of expertise. Number 3
column8: if the people really have a mind to change
column9: they can. You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress.  Now
column10: let me tell you what I favor instead. I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress
column11: strict limits on political action committees
column12: requirements that people running for Congress appear in open public debates like we're doing now. If you did that you could take away the incumbents' advantage because challengers like me would have a chance to run against incumbents like him for House races and Senate races
column13: and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight.  So that's how I feel about it
column14: and I think if we had the right kind of campaign reform
column15: we'd get the changes you want.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 7)	" Any order? I'll be glad to respond.

column1: I strongly support term limits for members of the US Congress. I believe it would return the government closer to the people
column2: the way that Ross Perot is talking about. The president's terms are limited to 2
column3: a total of 8 years. What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12? Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized. For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives
column4: and the result
column5: a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together. We've got to do something about it. And I think you get a certain arrogance
column6: bureaucratic arrogance
column7: if people stay there too long. And so I favor
column8: strongly favor
column9: term limits.  And how to get them passed? Send us some people that will pass the idea. And I think you will. I think the American people want it now. Every place I go I talk about it
column10: and I think they want it done. Actually
column11: you'd have to have some amendments to the Constitution because of the way the Constitution reads.

column1: I know they're popular
column2: but I'm against them. I'll tell you why. I believe
column3: number one
column4: it would pose a real problem for a lot of smaller states in the Congress who have enough trouble now making sure their interests are heard. Number 2
column5: I think it would increase the influence of unelected staff members in the Congress who have too much influence already. I want to cut the size of the congressional staffs
column6: but I think you're going to have too much influence there with people who were never elected
column7: who have lots of expertise. Number 3
column8: if the people really have a mind to change
column9: they can. You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress.  Now
column10: let me tell you what I favor instead. I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress
column11: strict limits on political action committees
column12: requirements that people running for Congress appear in open public debates like we're doing now. If you did that you could take away the incumbents' advantage because challengers like me would have a chance to run against incumbents like him for House races and Senate races
column13: and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight.  So that's how I feel about it
column14: and I think if we had the right kind of campaign reform
column15: we'd get the changes you want.

column1: Yes. Let me do first on a personal level. If the American people send me up to do this job
column2: I intend to be there one term. I do not intend to spend one minute of one day thinking about re-election. And as a matter of principle -- and my situation is unique
column3: and I understand it -- I would take absolutely no compensation; I go as their servant. Now
column4: I have set as strong an example as I can
column5: then at that point when we sit down over at Capitol Hill -- tomorrow night I'm going to be talking about government reform -- it's a long subject
column6: you wouldn't let me finish tonight. If you want to hear it
column7: you get it tomorrow night -- you'll hear it tomorrow night.  But we have got to reform government. If you put term limits in and don't reform government
column8: you won't get the benefits you thought. It takes both. So we need to do the reforms and the term limits. And after we reform it
column9: it won't be a lifetime career opportunity; good people will go serve and then go back to their homes and not become foreign lobbyists and cash in at 30
column10: 000 bucks a month and then take time off to run some president's campaign.  They're all nice people
column11: they're just in a bad system. I don't think there are any villains
column12: but
column13: boy
column14: is the system rotten.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 8)	" I've had more people talk to me about their health care problems I guess than anything else
column4: all across America -- you know
column6: lost their businesses
column7: had to give up their jobs because of sick children. So let me try to answer you in this way. Let's start with a premise. We spend 30% more of our income than any nation on earth on health care
column8: and yet we insure fewer people. We have 35 million people without any insurance at all -- and I see them all the time. A hundred thousand Americans a month have lost their health insurance just in the last 4 years. So if you analyze where we're out of line with other countries
column9: you come up with the following conclusions. Number one
column10: we spend at least $60 billion a year on insurance
column11: administrative cost
column12: bureaucracy
column13: and government regulation that wouldn't be spent in any other nation. So we have to have
column14: in my judgment
column15: a drastic simplification of the basic health insurance policies of this country
column16: be very comprehensive for everybody.  Employers would cover their employees
column17: government would cover the unemployed.  Number 2
column18: I think you have to take on specifically the insurance companies and require them to make some significant change in the way they rate people in the big community pools. I think you have to tell the pharmaceutical companies they can't keep raising drug prices at three times the rate of inflation. I think you have to take on medical fraud. I think you have to help doctors stop practicing defensive medicine. I've recommended that our doctors be given a set of national practice guidelines and that if they follow those guidelines that raises the presumption that they didn't do anything wrong.  I think you have to have a system of primary and preventive clinics in our inner cities and our rural areas so people can have access to health care.  The key is to control the cost and maintain the quality. To do that you need a system of managed competition where all of us are covered in big groups and we can choose our doctors and our hospitals
column20: but there is an incentive to control costs. And I think there has to be -- I think Mr. Perot and I agree on this
column21: there has to be a national commission of health care providers and health care consumers that set ceilings to keep health costs in line with inflation
column23: let me say
column24: some people say we can't do this but Hawaii does it. They cover 98% of their people and their insurance premiums are much cheaper than the rest of America
column26: New York. They now have a plan to cover everybody and their premiums are two-thirds of the rest of the country.  This is very important. It's a big human problem and a devastating economic problem for America
column27: and I'm going to send a plan to do this within the first 100 days of my presidency. It's terribly important.

column1: I just have to say something. I don't want to stampede. Ross was very articulate across the country. I don't want anybody to stampede to cut the president's salary off altogether. Barbara's sitting over here and I -- but what I have proposed
column2: 10% cut
column3: downsize the government
column4: and we can get that done. She asked a question
column6: is whether the health care profession was to blame. No. One thing to blame is these malpractice lawsuits. They're breaking the system. It costs $20-25 billion a year
column7: and I want to see those outrageous claims capped. Doctors don't dare to deliver babies sometimes because they're afraid that somebody's going to sue them. People don't dare -- medical practitioners
column8: to help somebody along the highway that are hurt because they're afraid that some lawyer's going to come along and get a big lawsuit. So you can't blame the practitioners for the health problem.  And my program is this. Keep the government as far out of it as possible
column9: make insurance available to the poorest of the poor
column10: through vouchers
column11: next range in the income bracket
column12: through tax credits
column13: and get on about the business of pooling insurance. A great big company can buy -- Ross has got a good-sized company
column14: been very successful. He can buy insurance cheaper than Mom and Pop's store on the corner. But if those Mom and Pop stores all get together and pool
column15: they too can bring the cost of insurance down.  So I want to keep the quality of health care. That means keep government out of it. I want to do -- I don't like this idea of these boards. It all sounds to me like you're going to have some government setting price. I want competition and I want to pool the insurance and take care of it that way and have -- oh
column16: here's the other point.  I think medical care should go with the person. If you leave a business
column17: I think your insurance should go with you to some other business. You shouldn't be worrying if you get a new job as to whether that's gonna -- and part of our plan is to make it what they call portable -- big word
column18: but that means if you're working for the Jones Company and you go to the Smith Company
column19: your insurance goes with you. I think it's a good program. I'm really excited about getting it done
column20: too.

column1: We have the most expensive health care system in the world. Twelve percent of our gross national product goes to health care. Our industrial competitors
column2: who are beating us in competition
column3: spend less and have better health care. Japan spends a little over 6% of its gross national product. Germany spends 8%. It's fascinating. You've bought a front row box seat and you're not happy with your health care and you're saying tonight we've got bad health care but very expensive health care. Folks
column4: here's why. Go home and look in the mirror.  You own this country but you have no voice in it the way it's organized now
column5: and if you want to have a high risk experience
column6: comparable to bungee jumping
column7: go into Congress some time when they're working on this kind of legislation
column8: when the lobbyists are running up and down the halls. Wear your safety toe shoes when you go. And as a private citizen
column9: believe me
column10: you are looked on as a major nuisance.  The facts are you now have a government that comes at you. You're supposed to have a government that comes from you.  Now
column11: there are all kinds of good ideas
column12: brilliant ideas
column13: terrific ideas on health care. None of them ever get implemented because -- let me give you an example. A senator runs every 6 years. He's got to raise 20
column14: 000 bucks a week to have enough money to run. Who's he gonna listen to -- us or the folks running up and down the aisles with money
column15: the lobbyists
column16: the PAC money? He listens to them. Who do they represent? Health care industry. Not us.  Now
column17: you've got to have a government that comes from you again. You've got to reassert your ownership in this country and you've got to completely reform our government. And at that point they'll just be like apples falling out of a tree. The programs will be good because the elected officials will be listening to -- I said the other night I was all ears and I would listen to any good idea. I think we ought to do plastic surgery on a lot of these guys so that they're all ears
column18: too
column19: and listen to you. Then you get what you want
column20: and shouldn't you? You paid for it. Why shouldn't you get what you want
column21: as opposed to what some lobbyist cuts a deal
column22: writes a little piece in the law and he goes through. That's the way the game's played now. Till you change it you're gonna be unhappy.

column1: One brief point. We have elections so people can make decisions about this. The point I want to make to you is
column2: a bipartisan commission reviewed my plan and the Bush plan and there were as many Republicans as Democratic health care experts on it. They concluded that my plan would cover everybody and his would leave 27 million behind by the year 2000 and that my plan in the next 12 years would save $2.2 trillion in public and private money to reinvest in this economy and the average family would save $1200 a year under the plan that I offered without any erosion in the quality of health care. So I ask you to look at that. And you have to vote for somebody with a plan. That's what you have elections for. If people would say
column3: well
column4: he got elected to do this and then the Congress says
column6: I'm going to do it. That's what the election was about.

column3: 8)	" I've had more people talk to me about their health care problems I guess than anything else
column4: all across America -- you know
column6: lost their businesses
column7: had to give up their jobs because of sick children. So let me try to answer you in this way. Let's start with a premise. We spend 30% more of our income than any nation on earth on health care
column8: and yet we insure fewer people. We have 35 million people without any insurance at all -- and I see them all the time. A hundred thousand Americans a month have lost their health insurance just in the last 4 years. So if you analyze where we're out of line with other countries
column9: you come up with the following conclusions. Number one
column10: we spend at least $60 billion a year on insurance
column11: administrative cost
column12: bureaucracy
column13: and government regulation that wouldn't be spent in any other nation. So we have to have
column14: in my judgment
column15: a drastic simplification of the basic health insurance policies of this country
column16: be very comprehensive for everybody.  Employers would cover their employees
column17: government would cover the unemployed.  Number 2
column18: I think you have to take on specifically the insurance companies and require them to make some significant change in the way they rate people in the big community pools. I think you have to tell the pharmaceutical companies they can't keep raising drug prices at three times the rate of inflation. I think you have to take on medical fraud. I think you have to help doctors stop practicing defensive medicine. I've recommended that our doctors be given a set of national practice guidelines and that if they follow those guidelines that raises the presumption that they didn't do anything wrong.  I think you have to have a system of primary and preventive clinics in our inner cities and our rural areas so people can have access to health care.  The key is to control the cost and maintain the quality. To do that you need a system of managed competition where all of us are covered in big groups and we can choose our doctors and our hospitals
column20: but there is an incentive to control costs. And I think there has to be -- I think Mr. Perot and I agree on this
column21: there has to be a national commission of health care providers and health care consumers that set ceilings to keep health costs in line with inflation
column23: let me say
column24: some people say we can't do this but Hawaii does it. They cover 98% of their people and their insurance premiums are much cheaper than the rest of America
column26: New York. They now have a plan to cover everybody and their premiums are two-thirds of the rest of the country.  This is very important. It's a big human problem and a devastating economic problem for America
column27: and I'm going to send a plan to do this within the first 100 days of my presidency. It's terribly important.

column1: I just have to say something. I don't want to stampede. Ross was very articulate across the country. I don't want anybody to stampede to cut the president's salary off altogether. Barbara's sitting over here and I -- but what I have proposed
column2: 10% cut
column3: downsize the government
column4: and we can get that done. She asked a question
column6: is whether the health care profession was to blame. No. One thing to blame is these malpractice lawsuits. They're breaking the system. It costs $20-25 billion a year
column7: and I want to see those outrageous claims capped. Doctors don't dare to deliver babies sometimes because they're afraid that somebody's going to sue them. People don't dare -- medical practitioners
column8: to help somebody along the highway that are hurt because they're afraid that some lawyer's going to come along and get a big lawsuit. So you can't blame the practitioners for the health problem.  And my program is this. Keep the government as far out of it as possible
column9: make insurance available to the poorest of the poor
column10: through vouchers
column11: next range in the income bracket
column12: through tax credits
column13: and get on about the business of pooling insurance. A great big company can buy -- Ross has got a good-sized company
column14: been very successful. He can buy insurance cheaper than Mom and Pop's store on the corner. But if those Mom and Pop stores all get together and pool
column15: they too can bring the cost of insurance down.  So I want to keep the quality of health care. That means keep government out of it. I want to do -- I don't like this idea of these boards. It all sounds to me like you're going to have some government setting price. I want competition and I want to pool the insurance and take care of it that way and have -- oh
column16: here's the other point.  I think medical care should go with the person. If you leave a business
column17: I think your insurance should go with you to some other business. You shouldn't be worrying if you get a new job as to whether that's gonna -- and part of our plan is to make it what they call portable -- big word
column18: but that means if you're working for the Jones Company and you go to the Smith Company
column19: your insurance goes with you. I think it's a good program. I'm really excited about getting it done
column20: too.

column1: We have the most expensive health care system in the world. Twelve percent of our gross national product goes to health care. Our industrial competitors
column2: who are beating us in competition
column3: spend less and have better health care. Japan spends a little over 6% of its gross national product. Germany spends 8%. It's fascinating. You've bought a front row box seat and you're not happy with your health care and you're saying tonight we've got bad health care but very expensive health care. Folks
column4: here's why. Go home and look in the mirror.  You own this country but you have no voice in it the way it's organized now
column5: and if you want to have a high risk experience
column6: comparable to bungee jumping
column7: go into Congress some time when they're working on this kind of legislation
column8: when the lobbyists are running up and down the halls. Wear your safety toe shoes when you go. And as a private citizen
column9: believe me
column10: you are looked on as a major nuisance.  The facts are you now have a government that comes at you. You're supposed to have a government that comes from you.  Now
column11: there are all kinds of good ideas
column12: brilliant ideas
column13: terrific ideas on health care. None of them ever get implemented because -- let me give you an example. A senator runs every 6 years. He's got to raise 20
column14: 000 bucks a week to have enough money to run. Who's he gonna listen to -- us or the folks running up and down the aisles with money
column15: the lobbyists
column16: the PAC money? He listens to them. Who do they represent? Health care industry. Not us.  Now
column17: you've got to have a government that comes from you again. You've got to reassert your ownership in this country and you've got to completely reform our government. And at that point they'll just be like apples falling out of a tree. The programs will be good because the elected officials will be listening to -- I said the other night I was all ears and I would listen to any good idea. I think we ought to do plastic surgery on a lot of these guys so that they're all ears
column18: too
column19: and listen to you. Then you get what you want
column20: and shouldn't you? You paid for it. Why shouldn't you get what you want
column21: as opposed to what some lobbyist cuts a deal
column22: writes a little piece in the law and he goes through. That's the way the game's played now. Till you change it you're gonna be unhappy.

column1: One brief point. We have elections so people can make decisions about this. The point I want to make to you is
column2: a bipartisan commission reviewed my plan and the Bush plan and there were as many Republicans as Democratic health care experts on it. They concluded that my plan would cover everybody and his would leave 27 million behind by the year 2000 and that my plan in the next 12 years would save $2.2 trillion in public and private money to reinvest in this economy and the average family would save $1200 a year under the plan that I offered without any erosion in the quality of health care. So I ask you to look at that. And you have to vote for somebody with a plan. That's what you have elections for. If people would say
column3: well
column4: he got elected to do this and then the Congress says
column6: I'm going to do it. That's what the election was about.
