column2: '15Oct'
column3: 8)	" I've had more people talk to me about their health care problems I guess than anything else
column4: all across America -- you know
column6: lost their businesses
column7: had to give up their jobs because of sick children. So let me try to answer you in this way. Let's start with a premise. We spend 30% more of our income than any nation on earth on health care
column8: and yet we insure fewer people. We have 35 million people without any insurance at all -- and I see them all the time. A hundred thousand Americans a month have lost their health insurance just in the last 4 years. So if you analyze where we're out of line with other countries
column9: you come up with the following conclusions. Number one
column10: we spend at least $60 billion a year on insurance
column11: administrative cost
column12: bureaucracy
column13: and government regulation that wouldn't be spent in any other nation. So we have to have
column14: in my judgment
column15: a drastic simplification of the basic health insurance policies of this country
column16: be very comprehensive for everybody.  Employers would cover their employees
column17: government would cover the unemployed.  Number 2
column18: I think you have to take on specifically the insurance companies and require them to make some significant change in the way they rate people in the big community pools. I think you have to tell the pharmaceutical companies they can't keep raising drug prices at three times the rate of inflation. I think you have to take on medical fraud. I think you have to help doctors stop practicing defensive medicine. I've recommended that our doctors be given a set of national practice guidelines and that if they follow those guidelines that raises the presumption that they didn't do anything wrong.  I think you have to have a system of primary and preventive clinics in our inner cities and our rural areas so people can have access to health care.  The key is to control the cost and maintain the quality. To do that you need a system of managed competition where all of us are covered in big groups and we can choose our doctors and our hospitals
column20: but there is an incentive to control costs. And I think there has to be -- I think Mr. Perot and I agree on this
column21: there has to be a national commission of health care providers and health care consumers that set ceilings to keep health costs in line with inflation
column23: let me say
column24: some people say we can't do this but Hawaii does it. They cover 98% of their people and their insurance premiums are much cheaper than the rest of America
column26: New York. They now have a plan to cover everybody and their premiums are two-thirds of the rest of the country.  This is very important. It's a big human problem and a devastating economic problem for America
column27: and I'm going to send a plan to do this within the first 100 days of my presidency. It's terribly important.

column1: I just have to say something. I don't want to stampede. Ross was very articulate across the country. I don't want anybody to stampede to cut the president's salary off altogether. Barbara's sitting over here and I -- but what I have proposed
column2: 10% cut
column3: downsize the government
column4: and we can get that done. She asked a question
column6: is whether the health care profession was to blame. No. One thing to blame is these malpractice lawsuits. They're breaking the system. It costs $20-25 billion a year
column7: and I want to see those outrageous claims capped. Doctors don't dare to deliver babies sometimes because they're afraid that somebody's going to sue them. People don't dare -- medical practitioners
column8: to help somebody along the highway that are hurt because they're afraid that some lawyer's going to come along and get a big lawsuit. So you can't blame the practitioners for the health problem.  And my program is this. Keep the government as far out of it as possible
column9: make insurance available to the poorest of the poor
column10: through vouchers
column11: next range in the income bracket
column12: through tax credits
column13: and get on about the business of pooling insurance. A great big company can buy -- Ross has got a good-sized company
column14: been very successful. He can buy insurance cheaper than Mom and Pop's store on the corner. But if those Mom and Pop stores all get together and pool
column15: they too can bring the cost of insurance down.  So I want to keep the quality of health care. That means keep government out of it. I want to do -- I don't like this idea of these boards. It all sounds to me like you're going to have some government setting price. I want competition and I want to pool the insurance and take care of it that way and have -- oh
column16: here's the other point.  I think medical care should go with the person. If you leave a business
column17: I think your insurance should go with you to some other business. You shouldn't be worrying if you get a new job as to whether that's gonna -- and part of our plan is to make it what they call portable -- big word
column18: but that means if you're working for the Jones Company and you go to the Smith Company
column19: your insurance goes with you. I think it's a good program. I'm really excited about getting it done
column20: too.

column1: We have the most expensive health care system in the world. Twelve percent of our gross national product goes to health care. Our industrial competitors
column2: who are beating us in competition
column3: spend less and have better health care. Japan spends a little over 6% of its gross national product. Germany spends 8%. It's fascinating. You've bought a front row box seat and you're not happy with your health care and you're saying tonight we've got bad health care but very expensive health care. Folks
column4: here's why. Go home and look in the mirror.  You own this country but you have no voice in it the way it's organized now
column5: and if you want to have a high risk experience
column6: comparable to bungee jumping
column7: go into Congress some time when they're working on this kind of legislation
column8: when the lobbyists are running up and down the halls. Wear your safety toe shoes when you go. And as a private citizen
column9: believe me
column10: you are looked on as a major nuisance.  The facts are you now have a government that comes at you. You're supposed to have a government that comes from you.  Now
column11: there are all kinds of good ideas
column12: brilliant ideas
column13: terrific ideas on health care. None of them ever get implemented because -- let me give you an example. A senator runs every 6 years. He's got to raise 20
column14: 000 bucks a week to have enough money to run. Who's he gonna listen to -- us or the folks running up and down the aisles with money
column15: the lobbyists
column16: the PAC money? He listens to them. Who do they represent? Health care industry. Not us.  Now
column17: you've got to have a government that comes from you again. You've got to reassert your ownership in this country and you've got to completely reform our government. And at that point they'll just be like apples falling out of a tree. The programs will be good because the elected officials will be listening to -- I said the other night I was all ears and I would listen to any good idea. I think we ought to do plastic surgery on a lot of these guys so that they're all ears
column18: too
column19: and listen to you. Then you get what you want
column20: and shouldn't you? You paid for it. Why shouldn't you get what you want
column21: as opposed to what some lobbyist cuts a deal
column22: writes a little piece in the law and he goes through. That's the way the game's played now. Till you change it you're gonna be unhappy.

column1: One brief point. We have elections so people can make decisions about this. The point I want to make to you is
column2: a bipartisan commission reviewed my plan and the Bush plan and there were as many Republicans as Democratic health care experts on it. They concluded that my plan would cover everybody and his would leave 27 million behind by the year 2000 and that my plan in the next 12 years would save $2.2 trillion in public and private money to reinvest in this economy and the average family would save $1200 a year under the plan that I offered without any erosion in the quality of health care. So I ask you to look at that. And you have to vote for somebody with a plan. That's what you have elections for. If people would say
column3: well
column4: he got elected to do this and then the Congress says
column6: I'm going to do it. That's what the election was about.

column1: This is very important. It's a big human problem and a devastating economic problem for America, and I'm going to send a plan to do this within the first 100 days of my presidency. It's terribly important. column3: 8)	" I've had more people talk to me about their health care problems I guess than anything else
column4: all across America -- you know
column6: lost their businesses
column7: had to give up their jobs because of sick children. So let me try to answer you in this way. Let's start with a premise. We spend 30% more of our income than any nation on earth on health care
column8: and yet we insure fewer people. We have 35 million people without any insurance at all -- and I see them all the time. A hundred thousand Americans a month have lost their health insurance just in the last 4 years. So if you analyze where we're out of line with other countries
column9: you come up with the following conclusions. Number one
column10: we spend at least $60 billion a year on insurance
column11: administrative cost
column12: bureaucracy
column13: and government regulation that wouldn't be spent in any other nation. So we have to have
column14: in my judgment
column15: a drastic simplification of the basic health insurance policies of this country
column16: be very comprehensive for everybody.  Employers would cover their employees
column17: government would cover the unemployed.  Number 2
column18: I think you have to take on specifically the insurance companies and require them to make some significant change in the way they rate people in the big community pools. I think you have to tell the pharmaceutical companies they can't keep raising drug prices at three times the rate of inflation. I think you have to take on medical fraud. I think you have to help doctors stop practicing defensive medicine. I've recommended that our doctors be given a set of national practice guidelines and that if they follow those guidelines that raises the presumption that they didn't do anything wrong.  I think you have to have a system of primary and preventive clinics in our inner cities and our rural areas so people can have access to health care.  The key is to control the cost and maintain the quality. To do that you need a system of managed competition where all of us are covered in big groups and we can choose our doctors and our hospitals
column20: but there is an incentive to control costs. And I think there has to be -- I think Mr. Perot and I agree on this
column21: there has to be a national commission of health care providers and health care consumers that set ceilings to keep health costs in line with inflation
column23: let me say
column24: some people say we can't do this but Hawaii does it. They cover 98% of their people and their insurance premiums are much cheaper than the rest of America
column26: New York. They now have a plan to cover everybody and their premiums are two-thirds of the rest of the country.  This is very important. It's a big human problem and a devastating economic problem for America
column27: and I'm going to send a plan to do this within the first 100 days of my presidency. It's terribly important.

column1: I just have to say something. I don't want to stampede. Ross was very articulate across the country. I don't want anybody to stampede to cut the president's salary off altogether. Barbara's sitting over here and I -- but what I have proposed
column2: 10% cut
column3: downsize the government
column4: and we can get that done. She asked a question
column6: is whether the health care profession was to blame. No. One thing to blame is these malpractice lawsuits. They're breaking the system. It costs $20-25 billion a year
column7: and I want to see those outrageous claims capped. Doctors don't dare to deliver babies sometimes because they're afraid that somebody's going to sue them. People don't dare -- medical practitioners
column8: to help somebody along the highway that are hurt because they're afraid that some lawyer's going to come along and get a big lawsuit. So you can't blame the practitioners for the health problem.  And my program is this. Keep the government as far out of it as possible
column9: make insurance available to the poorest of the poor
column10: through vouchers
column11: next range in the income bracket
column12: through tax credits
column13: and get on about the business of pooling insurance. A great big company can buy -- Ross has got a good-sized company
column14: been very successful. He can buy insurance cheaper than Mom and Pop's store on the corner. But if those Mom and Pop stores all get together and pool
column15: they too can bring the cost of insurance down.  So I want to keep the quality of health care. That means keep government out of it. I want to do -- I don't like this idea of these boards. It all sounds to me like you're going to have some government setting price. I want competition and I want to pool the insurance and take care of it that way and have -- oh
column16: here's the other point.  I think medical care should go with the person. If you leave a business
column17: I think your insurance should go with you to some other business. You shouldn't be worrying if you get a new job as to whether that's gonna -- and part of our plan is to make it what they call portable -- big word
column18: but that means if you're working for the Jones Company and you go to the Smith Company
column19: your insurance goes with you. I think it's a good program. I'm really excited about getting it done
column20: too.

column1: We have the most expensive health care system in the world. Twelve percent of our gross national product goes to health care. Our industrial competitors
column2: who are beating us in competition
column3: spend less and have better health care. Japan spends a little over 6% of its gross national product. Germany spends 8%. It's fascinating. You've bought a front row box seat and you're not happy with your health care and you're saying tonight we've got bad health care but very expensive health care. Folks
column4: here's why. Go home and look in the mirror.  You own this country but you have no voice in it the way it's organized now
column5: and if you want to have a high risk experience
column6: comparable to bungee jumping
column7: go into Congress some time when they're working on this kind of legislation
column8: when the lobbyists are running up and down the halls. Wear your safety toe shoes when you go. And as a private citizen
column9: believe me
column10: you are looked on as a major nuisance.  The facts are you now have a government that comes at you. You're supposed to have a government that comes from you.  Now
column11: there are all kinds of good ideas
column12: brilliant ideas
column13: terrific ideas on health care. None of them ever get implemented because -- let me give you an example. A senator runs every 6 years. He's got to raise 20
column14: 000 bucks a week to have enough money to run. Who's he gonna listen to -- us or the folks running up and down the aisles with money
column15: the lobbyists
column16: the PAC money? He listens to them. Who do they represent? Health care industry. Not us.  Now
column17: you've got to have a government that comes from you again. You've got to reassert your ownership in this country and you've got to completely reform our government. And at that point they'll just be like apples falling out of a tree. The programs will be good because the elected officials will be listening to -- I said the other night I was all ears and I would listen to any good idea. I think we ought to do plastic surgery on a lot of these guys so that they're all ears
column18: too
column19: and listen to you. Then you get what you want
column20: and shouldn't you? You paid for it. Why shouldn't you get what you want
column21: as opposed to what some lobbyist cuts a deal
column22: writes a little piece in the law and he goes through. That's the way the game's played now. Till you change it you're gonna be unhappy.

column1: One brief point. We have elections so people can make decisions about this. The point I want to make to you is
column2: a bipartisan commission reviewed my plan and the Bush plan and there were as many Republicans as Democratic health care experts on it. They concluded that my plan would cover everybody and his would leave 27 million behind by the year 2000 and that my plan in the next 12 years would save $2.2 trillion in public and private money to reinvest in this economy and the average family would save $1200 a year under the plan that I offered without any erosion in the quality of health care. So I ask you to look at that. And you have to vote for somebody with a plan. That's what you have elections for. If people would say
column3: well
column4: he got elected to do this and then the Congress says
column6: I'm going to do it. That's what the election was about.

column3: 8)	" I've had more people talk to me about their health care problems I guess than anything else
column4: all across America -- you know
column6: lost their businesses
column7: had to give up their jobs because of sick children. So let me try to answer you in this way. Let's start with a premise. We spend 30% more of our income than any nation on earth on health care
column8: and yet we insure fewer people. We have 35 million people without any insurance at all -- and I see them all the time. A hundred thousand Americans a month have lost their health insurance just in the last 4 years. So if you analyze where we're out of line with other countries
column9: you come up with the following conclusions. Number one
column10: we spend at least $60 billion a year on insurance
column11: administrative cost
column12: bureaucracy
column13: and government regulation that wouldn't be spent in any other nation. So we have to have
column14: in my judgment
column15: a drastic simplification of the basic health insurance policies of this country
column16: be very comprehensive for everybody.  Employers would cover their employees
column17: government would cover the unemployed.  Number 2
column18: I think you have to take on specifically the insurance companies and require them to make some significant change in the way they rate people in the big community pools. I think you have to tell the pharmaceutical companies they can't keep raising drug prices at three times the rate of inflation. I think you have to take on medical fraud. I think you have to help doctors stop practicing defensive medicine. I've recommended that our doctors be given a set of national practice guidelines and that if they follow those guidelines that raises the presumption that they didn't do anything wrong.  I think you have to have a system of primary and preventive clinics in our inner cities and our rural areas so people can have access to health care.  The key is to control the cost and maintain the quality. To do that you need a system of managed competition where all of us are covered in big groups and we can choose our doctors and our hospitals
column20: but there is an incentive to control costs. And I think there has to be -- I think Mr. Perot and I agree on this
column21: there has to be a national commission of health care providers and health care consumers that set ceilings to keep health costs in line with inflation
column23: let me say
column24: some people say we can't do this but Hawaii does it. They cover 98% of their people and their insurance premiums are much cheaper than the rest of America
column26: New York. They now have a plan to cover everybody and their premiums are two-thirds of the rest of the country.  This is very important. It's a big human problem and a devastating economic problem for America
column27: and I'm going to send a plan to do this within the first 100 days of my presidency. It's terribly important.

column1: I just have to say something. I don't want to stampede. Ross was very articulate across the country. I don't want anybody to stampede to cut the president's salary off altogether. Barbara's sitting over here and I -- but what I have proposed
column2: 10% cut
column3: downsize the government
column4: and we can get that done. She asked a question
column6: is whether the health care profession was to blame. No. One thing to blame is these malpractice lawsuits. They're breaking the system. It costs $20-25 billion a year
column7: and I want to see those outrageous claims capped. Doctors don't dare to deliver babies sometimes because they're afraid that somebody's going to sue them. People don't dare -- medical practitioners
column8: to help somebody along the highway that are hurt because they're afraid that some lawyer's going to come along and get a big lawsuit. So you can't blame the practitioners for the health problem.  And my program is this. Keep the government as far out of it as possible
column9: make insurance available to the poorest of the poor
column10: through vouchers
column11: next range in the income bracket
column12: through tax credits
column13: and get on about the business of pooling insurance. A great big company can buy -- Ross has got a good-sized company
column14: been very successful. He can buy insurance cheaper than Mom and Pop's store on the corner. But if those Mom and Pop stores all get together and pool
column15: they too can bring the cost of insurance down.  So I want to keep the quality of health care. That means keep government out of it. I want to do -- I don't like this idea of these boards. It all sounds to me like you're going to have some government setting price. I want competition and I want to pool the insurance and take care of it that way and have -- oh
column16: here's the other point.  I think medical care should go with the person. If you leave a business
column17: I think your insurance should go with you to some other business. You shouldn't be worrying if you get a new job as to whether that's gonna -- and part of our plan is to make it what they call portable -- big word
column18: but that means if you're working for the Jones Company and you go to the Smith Company
column19: your insurance goes with you. I think it's a good program. I'm really excited about getting it done
column20: too.

column1: We have the most expensive health care system in the world. Twelve percent of our gross national product goes to health care. Our industrial competitors
column2: who are beating us in competition
column3: spend less and have better health care. Japan spends a little over 6% of its gross national product. Germany spends 8%. It's fascinating. You've bought a front row box seat and you're not happy with your health care and you're saying tonight we've got bad health care but very expensive health care. Folks
column4: here's why. Go home and look in the mirror.  You own this country but you have no voice in it the way it's organized now
column5: and if you want to have a high risk experience
column6: comparable to bungee jumping
column7: go into Congress some time when they're working on this kind of legislation
column8: when the lobbyists are running up and down the halls. Wear your safety toe shoes when you go. And as a private citizen
column9: believe me
column10: you are looked on as a major nuisance.  The facts are you now have a government that comes at you. You're supposed to have a government that comes from you.  Now
column11: there are all kinds of good ideas
column12: brilliant ideas
column13: terrific ideas on health care. None of them ever get implemented because -- let me give you an example. A senator runs every 6 years. He's got to raise 20
column14: 000 bucks a week to have enough money to run. Who's he gonna listen to -- us or the folks running up and down the aisles with money
column15: the lobbyists
column16: the PAC money? He listens to them. Who do they represent? Health care industry. Not us.  Now
column17: you've got to have a government that comes from you again. You've got to reassert your ownership in this country and you've got to completely reform our government. And at that point they'll just be like apples falling out of a tree. The programs will be good because the elected officials will be listening to -- I said the other night I was all ears and I would listen to any good idea. I think we ought to do plastic surgery on a lot of these guys so that they're all ears
column18: too
column19: and listen to you. Then you get what you want
column20: and shouldn't you? You paid for it. Why shouldn't you get what you want
column21: as opposed to what some lobbyist cuts a deal
column22: writes a little piece in the law and he goes through. That's the way the game's played now. Till you change it you're gonna be unhappy.

column1: One brief point. We have elections so people can make decisions about this. The point I want to make to you is
column2: a bipartisan commission reviewed my plan and the Bush plan and there were as many Republicans as Democratic health care experts on it. They concluded that my plan would cover everybody and his would leave 27 million behind by the year 2000 and that my plan in the next 12 years would save $2.2 trillion in public and private money to reinvest in this economy and the average family would save $1200 a year under the plan that I offered without any erosion in the quality of health care. So I ask you to look at that. And you have to vote for somebody with a plan. That's what you have elections for. If people would say
column3: well
column4: he got elected to do this and then the Congress says
column6: I'm going to do it. That's what the election was about.

column3: 8)	" I've had more people talk to me about their health care problems I guess than anything else
column4: all across America -- you know
column6: lost their businesses
column7: had to give up their jobs because of sick children. So let me try to answer you in this way. Let's start with a premise. We spend 30% more of our income than any nation on earth on health care
column8: and yet we insure fewer people. We have 35 million people without any insurance at all -- and I see them all the time. A hundred thousand Americans a month have lost their health insurance just in the last 4 years. So if you analyze where we're out of line with other countries
column9: you come up with the following conclusions. Number one
column10: we spend at least $60 billion a year on insurance
column11: administrative cost
column12: bureaucracy
column13: and government regulation that wouldn't be spent in any other nation. So we have to have
column14: in my judgment
column15: a drastic simplification of the basic health insurance policies of this country
column16: be very comprehensive for everybody.  Employers would cover their employees
column17: government would cover the unemployed.  Number 2
column18: I think you have to take on specifically the insurance companies and require them to make some significant change in the way they rate people in the big community pools. I think you have to tell the pharmaceutical companies they can't keep raising drug prices at three times the rate of inflation. I think you have to take on medical fraud. I think you have to help doctors stop practicing defensive medicine. I've recommended that our doctors be given a set of national practice guidelines and that if they follow those guidelines that raises the presumption that they didn't do anything wrong.  I think you have to have a system of primary and preventive clinics in our inner cities and our rural areas so people can have access to health care.  The key is to control the cost and maintain the quality. To do that you need a system of managed competition where all of us are covered in big groups and we can choose our doctors and our hospitals
column20: but there is an incentive to control costs. And I think there has to be -- I think Mr. Perot and I agree on this
column21: there has to be a national commission of health care providers and health care consumers that set ceilings to keep health costs in line with inflation
column23: let me say
column24: some people say we can't do this but Hawaii does it. They cover 98% of their people and their insurance premiums are much cheaper than the rest of America
column26: New York. They now have a plan to cover everybody and their premiums are two-thirds of the rest of the country.  This is very important. It's a big human problem and a devastating economic problem for America
column27: and I'm going to send a plan to do this within the first 100 days of my presidency. It's terribly important.

column1: I just have to say something. I don't want to stampede. Ross was very articulate across the country. I don't want anybody to stampede to cut the president's salary off altogether. Barbara's sitting over here and I -- but what I have proposed
column2: 10% cut
column3: downsize the government
column4: and we can get that done. She asked a question
column6: is whether the health care profession was to blame. No. One thing to blame is these malpractice lawsuits. They're breaking the system. It costs $20-25 billion a year
column7: and I want to see those outrageous claims capped. Doctors don't dare to deliver babies sometimes because they're afraid that somebody's going to sue them. People don't dare -- medical practitioners
column8: to help somebody along the highway that are hurt because they're afraid that some lawyer's going to come along and get a big lawsuit. So you can't blame the practitioners for the health problem.  And my program is this. Keep the government as far out of it as possible
column9: make insurance available to the poorest of the poor
column10: through vouchers
column11: next range in the income bracket
column12: through tax credits
column13: and get on about the business of pooling insurance. A great big company can buy -- Ross has got a good-sized company
column14: been very successful. He can buy insurance cheaper than Mom and Pop's store on the corner. But if those Mom and Pop stores all get together and pool
column15: they too can bring the cost of insurance down.  So I want to keep the quality of health care. That means keep government out of it. I want to do -- I don't like this idea of these boards. It all sounds to me like you're going to have some government setting price. I want competition and I want to pool the insurance and take care of it that way and have -- oh
column16: here's the other point.  I think medical care should go with the person. If you leave a business
column17: I think your insurance should go with you to some other business. You shouldn't be worrying if you get a new job as to whether that's gonna -- and part of our plan is to make it what they call portable -- big word
column18: but that means if you're working for the Jones Company and you go to the Smith Company
column19: your insurance goes with you. I think it's a good program. I'm really excited about getting it done
column20: too.

column1: We have the most expensive health care system in the world. Twelve percent of our gross national product goes to health care. Our industrial competitors
column2: who are beating us in competition
column3: spend less and have better health care. Japan spends a little over 6% of its gross national product. Germany spends 8%. It's fascinating. You've bought a front row box seat and you're not happy with your health care and you're saying tonight we've got bad health care but very expensive health care. Folks
column4: here's why. Go home and look in the mirror.  You own this country but you have no voice in it the way it's organized now
column5: and if you want to have a high risk experience
column6: comparable to bungee jumping
column7: go into Congress some time when they're working on this kind of legislation
column8: when the lobbyists are running up and down the halls. Wear your safety toe shoes when you go. And as a private citizen
column9: believe me
column10: you are looked on as a major nuisance.  The facts are you now have a government that comes at you. You're supposed to have a government that comes from you.  Now
column11: there are all kinds of good ideas
column12: brilliant ideas
column13: terrific ideas on health care. None of them ever get implemented because -- let me give you an example. A senator runs every 6 years. He's got to raise 20
column14: 000 bucks a week to have enough money to run. Who's he gonna listen to -- us or the folks running up and down the aisles with money
column15: the lobbyists
column16: the PAC money? He listens to them. Who do they represent? Health care industry. Not us.  Now
column17: you've got to have a government that comes from you again. You've got to reassert your ownership in this country and you've got to completely reform our government. And at that point they'll just be like apples falling out of a tree. The programs will be good because the elected officials will be listening to -- I said the other night I was all ears and I would listen to any good idea. I think we ought to do plastic surgery on a lot of these guys so that they're all ears
column18: too
column19: and listen to you. Then you get what you want
column20: and shouldn't you? You paid for it. Why shouldn't you get what you want
column21: as opposed to what some lobbyist cuts a deal
column22: writes a little piece in the law and he goes through. That's the way the game's played now. Till you change it you're gonna be unhappy.

column1: One brief point. We have elections so people can make decisions about this. The point I want to make to you is
column2: a bipartisan commission reviewed my plan and the Bush plan and there were as many Republicans as Democratic health care experts on it. They concluded that my plan would cover everybody and his would leave 27 million behind by the year 2000 and that my plan in the next 12 years would save $2.2 trillion in public and private money to reinvest in this economy and the average family would save $1200 a year under the plan that I offered without any erosion in the quality of health care. So I ask you to look at that. And you have to vote for somebody with a plan. That's what you have elections for. If people would say
column3: well
column4: he got elected to do this and then the Congress says
column6: I'm going to do it. That's what the election was about.

column3: 8)	" I've had more people talk to me about their health care problems I guess than anything else
column4: all across America -- you know
column6: lost their businesses
column7: had to give up their jobs because of sick children. So let me try to answer you in this way. Let's start with a premise. We spend 30% more of our income than any nation on earth on health care
column8: and yet we insure fewer people. We have 35 million people without any insurance at all -- and I see them all the time. A hundred thousand Americans a month have lost their health insurance just in the last 4 years. So if you analyze where we're out of line with other countries
column9: you come up with the following conclusions. Number one
column10: we spend at least $60 billion a year on insurance
column11: administrative cost
column12: bureaucracy
column13: and government regulation that wouldn't be spent in any other nation. So we have to have
column14: in my judgment
column15: a drastic simplification of the basic health insurance policies of this country
column16: be very comprehensive for everybody.  Employers would cover their employees
column17: government would cover the unemployed.  Number 2
column18: I think you have to take on specifically the insurance companies and require them to make some significant change in the way they rate people in the big community pools. I think you have to tell the pharmaceutical companies they can't keep raising drug prices at three times the rate of inflation. I think you have to take on medical fraud. I think you have to help doctors stop practicing defensive medicine. I've recommended that our doctors be given a set of national practice guidelines and that if they follow those guidelines that raises the presumption that they didn't do anything wrong.  I think you have to have a system of primary and preventive clinics in our inner cities and our rural areas so people can have access to health care.  The key is to control the cost and maintain the quality. To do that you need a system of managed competition where all of us are covered in big groups and we can choose our doctors and our hospitals
column20: but there is an incentive to control costs. And I think there has to be -- I think Mr. Perot and I agree on this
column21: there has to be a national commission of health care providers and health care consumers that set ceilings to keep health costs in line with inflation
column23: let me say
column24: some people say we can't do this but Hawaii does it. They cover 98% of their people and their insurance premiums are much cheaper than the rest of America
column26: New York. They now have a plan to cover everybody and their premiums are two-thirds of the rest of the country.  This is very important. It's a big human problem and a devastating economic problem for America
column27: and I'm going to send a plan to do this within the first 100 days of my presidency. It's terribly important.

column1: I just have to say something. I don't want to stampede. Ross was very articulate across the country. I don't want anybody to stampede to cut the president's salary off altogether. Barbara's sitting over here and I -- but what I have proposed
column2: 10% cut
column3: downsize the government
column4: and we can get that done. She asked a question
column6: is whether the health care profession was to blame. No. One thing to blame is these malpractice lawsuits. They're breaking the system. It costs $20-25 billion a year
column7: and I want to see those outrageous claims capped. Doctors don't dare to deliver babies sometimes because they're afraid that somebody's going to sue them. People don't dare -- medical practitioners
column8: to help somebody along the highway that are hurt because they're afraid that some lawyer's going to come along and get a big lawsuit. So you can't blame the practitioners for the health problem.  And my program is this. Keep the government as far out of it as possible
column9: make insurance available to the poorest of the poor
column10: through vouchers
column11: next range in the income bracket
column12: through tax credits
column13: and get on about the business of pooling insurance. A great big company can buy -- Ross has got a good-sized company
column14: been very successful. He can buy insurance cheaper than Mom and Pop's store on the corner. But if those Mom and Pop stores all get together and pool
column15: they too can bring the cost of insurance down.  So I want to keep the quality of health care. That means keep government out of it. I want to do -- I don't like this idea of these boards. It all sounds to me like you're going to have some government setting price. I want competition and I want to pool the insurance and take care of it that way and have -- oh
column16: here's the other point.  I think medical care should go with the person. If you leave a business
column17: I think your insurance should go with you to some other business. You shouldn't be worrying if you get a new job as to whether that's gonna -- and part of our plan is to make it what they call portable -- big word
column18: but that means if you're working for the Jones Company and you go to the Smith Company
column19: your insurance goes with you. I think it's a good program. I'm really excited about getting it done
column20: too.

column1: We have the most expensive health care system in the world. Twelve percent of our gross national product goes to health care. Our industrial competitors
column2: who are beating us in competition
column3: spend less and have better health care. Japan spends a little over 6% of its gross national product. Germany spends 8%. It's fascinating. You've bought a front row box seat and you're not happy with your health care and you're saying tonight we've got bad health care but very expensive health care. Folks
column4: here's why. Go home and look in the mirror.  You own this country but you have no voice in it the way it's organized now
column5: and if you want to have a high risk experience
column6: comparable to bungee jumping
column7: go into Congress some time when they're working on this kind of legislation
column8: when the lobbyists are running up and down the halls. Wear your safety toe shoes when you go. And as a private citizen
column9: believe me
column10: you are looked on as a major nuisance.  The facts are you now have a government that comes at you. You're supposed to have a government that comes from you.  Now
column11: there are all kinds of good ideas
column12: brilliant ideas
column13: terrific ideas on health care. None of them ever get implemented because -- let me give you an example. A senator runs every 6 years. He's got to raise 20
column14: 000 bucks a week to have enough money to run. Who's he gonna listen to -- us or the folks running up and down the aisles with money
column15: the lobbyists
column16: the PAC money? He listens to them. Who do they represent? Health care industry. Not us.  Now
column17: you've got to have a government that comes from you again. You've got to reassert your ownership in this country and you've got to completely reform our government. And at that point they'll just be like apples falling out of a tree. The programs will be good because the elected officials will be listening to -- I said the other night I was all ears and I would listen to any good idea. I think we ought to do plastic surgery on a lot of these guys so that they're all ears
column18: too
column19: and listen to you. Then you get what you want
column20: and shouldn't you? You paid for it. Why shouldn't you get what you want
column21: as opposed to what some lobbyist cuts a deal
column22: writes a little piece in the law and he goes through. That's the way the game's played now. Till you change it you're gonna be unhappy.

column1: One brief point. We have elections so people can make decisions about this. The point I want to make to you is
column2: a bipartisan commission reviewed my plan and the Bush plan and there were as many Republicans as Democratic health care experts on it. They concluded that my plan would cover everybody and his would leave 27 million behind by the year 2000 and that my plan in the next 12 years would save $2.2 trillion in public and private money to reinvest in this economy and the average family would save $1200 a year under the plan that I offered without any erosion in the quality of health care. So I ask you to look at that. And you have to vote for somebody with a plan. That's what you have elections for. If people would say
column3: well
column4: he got elected to do this and then the Congress says
column6: I'm going to do it. That's what the election was about.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 8)	" I've had more people talk to me about their health care problems I guess than anything else
column4: all across America -- you know
column6: lost their businesses
column7: had to give up their jobs because of sick children. So let me try to answer you in this way. Let's start with a premise. We spend 30% more of our income than any nation on earth on health care
column8: and yet we insure fewer people. We have 35 million people without any insurance at all -- and I see them all the time. A hundred thousand Americans a month have lost their health insurance just in the last 4 years. So if you analyze where we're out of line with other countries
column9: you come up with the following conclusions. Number one
column10: we spend at least $60 billion a year on insurance
column11: administrative cost
column12: bureaucracy
column13: and government regulation that wouldn't be spent in any other nation. So we have to have
column14: in my judgment
column15: a drastic simplification of the basic health insurance policies of this country
column16: be very comprehensive for everybody.  Employers would cover their employees
column17: government would cover the unemployed.  Number 2
column18: I think you have to take on specifically the insurance companies and require them to make some significant change in the way they rate people in the big community pools. I think you have to tell the pharmaceutical companies they can't keep raising drug prices at three times the rate of inflation. I think you have to take on medical fraud. I think you have to help doctors stop practicing defensive medicine. I've recommended that our doctors be given a set of national practice guidelines and that if they follow those guidelines that raises the presumption that they didn't do anything wrong.  I think you have to have a system of primary and preventive clinics in our inner cities and our rural areas so people can have access to health care.  The key is to control the cost and maintain the quality. To do that you need a system of managed competition where all of us are covered in big groups and we can choose our doctors and our hospitals
column20: but there is an incentive to control costs. And I think there has to be -- I think Mr. Perot and I agree on this
column21: there has to be a national commission of health care providers and health care consumers that set ceilings to keep health costs in line with inflation
column23: let me say
column24: some people say we can't do this but Hawaii does it. They cover 98% of their people and their insurance premiums are much cheaper than the rest of America
column26: New York. They now have a plan to cover everybody and their premiums are two-thirds of the rest of the country.  This is very important. It's a big human problem and a devastating economic problem for America
column27: and I'm going to send a plan to do this within the first 100 days of my presidency. It's terribly important.

column1: I just have to say something. I don't want to stampede. Ross was very articulate across the country. I don't want anybody to stampede to cut the president's salary off altogether. Barbara's sitting over here and I -- but what I have proposed
column2: 10% cut
column3: downsize the government
column4: and we can get that done. She asked a question
column6: is whether the health care profession was to blame. No. One thing to blame is these malpractice lawsuits. They're breaking the system. It costs $20-25 billion a year
column7: and I want to see those outrageous claims capped. Doctors don't dare to deliver babies sometimes because they're afraid that somebody's going to sue them. People don't dare -- medical practitioners
column8: to help somebody along the highway that are hurt because they're afraid that some lawyer's going to come along and get a big lawsuit. So you can't blame the practitioners for the health problem.  And my program is this. Keep the government as far out of it as possible
column9: make insurance available to the poorest of the poor
column10: through vouchers
column11: next range in the income bracket
column12: through tax credits
column13: and get on about the business of pooling insurance. A great big company can buy -- Ross has got a good-sized company
column14: been very successful. He can buy insurance cheaper than Mom and Pop's store on the corner. But if those Mom and Pop stores all get together and pool
column15: they too can bring the cost of insurance down.  So I want to keep the quality of health care. That means keep government out of it. I want to do -- I don't like this idea of these boards. It all sounds to me like you're going to have some government setting price. I want competition and I want to pool the insurance and take care of it that way and have -- oh
column16: here's the other point.  I think medical care should go with the person. If you leave a business
column17: I think your insurance should go with you to some other business. You shouldn't be worrying if you get a new job as to whether that's gonna -- and part of our plan is to make it what they call portable -- big word
column18: but that means if you're working for the Jones Company and you go to the Smith Company
column19: your insurance goes with you. I think it's a good program. I'm really excited about getting it done
column20: too.

column1: We have the most expensive health care system in the world. Twelve percent of our gross national product goes to health care. Our industrial competitors
column2: who are beating us in competition
column3: spend less and have better health care. Japan spends a little over 6% of its gross national product. Germany spends 8%. It's fascinating. You've bought a front row box seat and you're not happy with your health care and you're saying tonight we've got bad health care but very expensive health care. Folks
column4: here's why. Go home and look in the mirror.  You own this country but you have no voice in it the way it's organized now
column5: and if you want to have a high risk experience
column6: comparable to bungee jumping
column7: go into Congress some time when they're working on this kind of legislation
column8: when the lobbyists are running up and down the halls. Wear your safety toe shoes when you go. And as a private citizen
column9: believe me
column10: you are looked on as a major nuisance.  The facts are you now have a government that comes at you. You're supposed to have a government that comes from you.  Now
column11: there are all kinds of good ideas
column12: brilliant ideas
column13: terrific ideas on health care. None of them ever get implemented because -- let me give you an example. A senator runs every 6 years. He's got to raise 20
column14: 000 bucks a week to have enough money to run. Who's he gonna listen to -- us or the folks running up and down the aisles with money
column15: the lobbyists
column16: the PAC money? He listens to them. Who do they represent? Health care industry. Not us.  Now
column17: you've got to have a government that comes from you again. You've got to reassert your ownership in this country and you've got to completely reform our government. And at that point they'll just be like apples falling out of a tree. The programs will be good because the elected officials will be listening to -- I said the other night I was all ears and I would listen to any good idea. I think we ought to do plastic surgery on a lot of these guys so that they're all ears
column18: too
column19: and listen to you. Then you get what you want
column20: and shouldn't you? You paid for it. Why shouldn't you get what you want
column21: as opposed to what some lobbyist cuts a deal
column22: writes a little piece in the law and he goes through. That's the way the game's played now. Till you change it you're gonna be unhappy.

column1: One brief point. We have elections so people can make decisions about this. The point I want to make to you is
column2: a bipartisan commission reviewed my plan and the Bush plan and there were as many Republicans as Democratic health care experts on it. They concluded that my plan would cover everybody and his would leave 27 million behind by the year 2000 and that my plan in the next 12 years would save $2.2 trillion in public and private money to reinvest in this economy and the average family would save $1200 a year under the plan that I offered without any erosion in the quality of health care. So I ask you to look at that. And you have to vote for somebody with a plan. That's what you have elections for. If people would say
column3: well
column4: he got elected to do this and then the Congress says
column6: I'm going to do it. That's what the election was about.

column3: 8)	" I've had more people talk to me about their health care problems I guess than anything else
column4: all across America -- you know
column6: lost their businesses
column7: had to give up their jobs because of sick children. So let me try to answer you in this way. Let's start with a premise. We spend 30% more of our income than any nation on earth on health care
column8: and yet we insure fewer people. We have 35 million people without any insurance at all -- and I see them all the time. A hundred thousand Americans a month have lost their health insurance just in the last 4 years. So if you analyze where we're out of line with other countries
column9: you come up with the following conclusions. Number one
column10: we spend at least $60 billion a year on insurance
column11: administrative cost
column12: bureaucracy
column13: and government regulation that wouldn't be spent in any other nation. So we have to have
column14: in my judgment
column15: a drastic simplification of the basic health insurance policies of this country
column16: be very comprehensive for everybody.  Employers would cover their employees
column17: government would cover the unemployed.  Number 2
column18: I think you have to take on specifically the insurance companies and require them to make some significant change in the way they rate people in the big community pools. I think you have to tell the pharmaceutical companies they can't keep raising drug prices at three times the rate of inflation. I think you have to take on medical fraud. I think you have to help doctors stop practicing defensive medicine. I've recommended that our doctors be given a set of national practice guidelines and that if they follow those guidelines that raises the presumption that they didn't do anything wrong.  I think you have to have a system of primary and preventive clinics in our inner cities and our rural areas so people can have access to health care.  The key is to control the cost and maintain the quality. To do that you need a system of managed competition where all of us are covered in big groups and we can choose our doctors and our hospitals
column20: but there is an incentive to control costs. And I think there has to be -- I think Mr. Perot and I agree on this
column21: there has to be a national commission of health care providers and health care consumers that set ceilings to keep health costs in line with inflation
column23: let me say
column24: some people say we can't do this but Hawaii does it. They cover 98% of their people and their insurance premiums are much cheaper than the rest of America
column26: New York. They now have a plan to cover everybody and their premiums are two-thirds of the rest of the country.  This is very important. It's a big human problem and a devastating economic problem for America
column27: and I'm going to send a plan to do this within the first 100 days of my presidency. It's terribly important.

column1: I just have to say something. I don't want to stampede. Ross was very articulate across the country. I don't want anybody to stampede to cut the president's salary off altogether. Barbara's sitting over here and I -- but what I have proposed
column2: 10% cut
column3: downsize the government
column4: and we can get that done. She asked a question
column6: is whether the health care profession was to blame. No. One thing to blame is these malpractice lawsuits. They're breaking the system. It costs $20-25 billion a year
column7: and I want to see those outrageous claims capped. Doctors don't dare to deliver babies sometimes because they're afraid that somebody's going to sue them. People don't dare -- medical practitioners
column8: to help somebody along the highway that are hurt because they're afraid that some lawyer's going to come along and get a big lawsuit. So you can't blame the practitioners for the health problem.  And my program is this. Keep the government as far out of it as possible
column9: make insurance available to the poorest of the poor
column10: through vouchers
column11: next range in the income bracket
column12: through tax credits
column13: and get on about the business of pooling insurance. A great big company can buy -- Ross has got a good-sized company
column14: been very successful. He can buy insurance cheaper than Mom and Pop's store on the corner. But if those Mom and Pop stores all get together and pool
column15: they too can bring the cost of insurance down.  So I want to keep the quality of health care. That means keep government out of it. I want to do -- I don't like this idea of these boards. It all sounds to me like you're going to have some government setting price. I want competition and I want to pool the insurance and take care of it that way and have -- oh
column16: here's the other point.  I think medical care should go with the person. If you leave a business
column17: I think your insurance should go with you to some other business. You shouldn't be worrying if you get a new job as to whether that's gonna -- and part of our plan is to make it what they call portable -- big word
column18: but that means if you're working for the Jones Company and you go to the Smith Company
column19: your insurance goes with you. I think it's a good program. I'm really excited about getting it done
column20: too.

column1: We have the most expensive health care system in the world. Twelve percent of our gross national product goes to health care. Our industrial competitors
column2: who are beating us in competition
column3: spend less and have better health care. Japan spends a little over 6% of its gross national product. Germany spends 8%. It's fascinating. You've bought a front row box seat and you're not happy with your health care and you're saying tonight we've got bad health care but very expensive health care. Folks
column4: here's why. Go home and look in the mirror.  You own this country but you have no voice in it the way it's organized now
column5: and if you want to have a high risk experience
column6: comparable to bungee jumping
column7: go into Congress some time when they're working on this kind of legislation
column8: when the lobbyists are running up and down the halls. Wear your safety toe shoes when you go. And as a private citizen
column9: believe me
column10: you are looked on as a major nuisance.  The facts are you now have a government that comes at you. You're supposed to have a government that comes from you.  Now
column11: there are all kinds of good ideas
column12: brilliant ideas
column13: terrific ideas on health care. None of them ever get implemented because -- let me give you an example. A senator runs every 6 years. He's got to raise 20
column14: 000 bucks a week to have enough money to run. Who's he gonna listen to -- us or the folks running up and down the aisles with money
column15: the lobbyists
column16: the PAC money? He listens to them. Who do they represent? Health care industry. Not us.  Now
column17: you've got to have a government that comes from you again. You've got to reassert your ownership in this country and you've got to completely reform our government. And at that point they'll just be like apples falling out of a tree. The programs will be good because the elected officials will be listening to -- I said the other night I was all ears and I would listen to any good idea. I think we ought to do plastic surgery on a lot of these guys so that they're all ears
column18: too
column19: and listen to you. Then you get what you want
column20: and shouldn't you? You paid for it. Why shouldn't you get what you want
column21: as opposed to what some lobbyist cuts a deal
column22: writes a little piece in the law and he goes through. That's the way the game's played now. Till you change it you're gonna be unhappy.

column1: One brief point. We have elections so people can make decisions about this. The point I want to make to you is
column2: a bipartisan commission reviewed my plan and the Bush plan and there were as many Republicans as Democratic health care experts on it. They concluded that my plan would cover everybody and his would leave 27 million behind by the year 2000 and that my plan in the next 12 years would save $2.2 trillion in public and private money to reinvest in this economy and the average family would save $1200 a year under the plan that I offered without any erosion in the quality of health care. So I ask you to look at that. And you have to vote for somebody with a plan. That's what you have elections for. If people would say
column3: well
column4: he got elected to do this and then the Congress says
column6: I'm going to do it. That's what the election was about.
